2: Ambient Aerosol Absorption Optical Thickness at 550nm
4: Optical thickness of atmospheric aerosols at wavelength 550 nanometers.

2: Surface Mass Balance Flux
4: Specific mass balance means the net rate at which ice is added per unit area at the land ice surface. Computed as the total surface mass balance on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell. A negative value means loss of ice

2: Ice Sheet Surface Mass Balance Flux
4: Specific mass balance means the net rate at which ice is added per unit area at the land ice surface. Computed as the total surface mass balance on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell. A negative value means loss of ice

2: Aerosol Level Asymmetry Parameter for Each Band
4: The asymmetry factor is the angular integral of the aerosol scattering phase function weighted by the cosine of the angle with the incident radiation flux. The asymmetry coefficient is here an integral over all wavelength bands.

2: Aerosol Level Absorption Optical Thickness for Each Band
4: Optical thickness of atmospheric aerosols in wavelength bands.

2: Aerosol Level Single Scattering Albedo for Each Band
4: The single scattering albedo is the fraction of radiation in an incident light beam scattered by the particles of an aerosol reference volume for a given wavelength. It is the ratio of the scattering and the extinction coefficients of the aerosol particles in the reference volume.

2: Mean Age of Snow
4: Age of Snow (when computing the time-mean here, the time samples, weighted by the mass of snow on the land portion of the grid cell, are accumulated and then divided by the sum of the weights.  Reported as missing data in regions free of snow on land.

2: Sea Water Age Since Surface Contact
4: Time elapsed since water was last in surface layer of the ocean.

2: Vertically Integrated Mass Content of Air in Layer
4: The mass of air in an atmospheric layer.

2: Canopy Albedo
4: Albedo of the vegetation: fraction of incoming solar radiation which is reflected before reaching the ground.

2: Diffuse Surface Albedo for Each Band
4: The fraction of the surface diffuse downwelling shortwave radiation flux which is reflected. If the diffuse radiation is isotropic, this term is equivalent to the integral of surface bidirectional reflectance over all incident angles and over all outgoing angles in the hemisphere above the surface. Reported in spectral frequency bands.

2: Direct Surface Albedo for Each Band
4: The fraction of the surface direct downwelling shortwave radiation flux which is reflected. It is equivalent to the surface bidirectional reflectance at the incident angle of the incoming solar radiation and integrated over all outgoing angles in the hemisphere above the surface.  Reported in spectral frequency bands.

2: ISCCP Mean Cloud Albedo
4: ISCCP Mean Cloud Albedo. Time-means are weighted by the ISCCP Total Cloud Fraction {:cltisccp} - see  http://cfmip.metoffice.com/COSP.html

2: Snow Albedo
4: Albedo of the snow-covered surface, averaged over the grid cell.

2: Northern Hemisphere Tracer Lifetime
4: Fixed surface layer mixing ratio over 30o-50oN (0 ppbv), uniform fixed source (at all levels) everywhere else (source is unspecified but must be constant in space and time and documented). Note that the source could be 1yr/yr, so the tracer concentration provides mean age in years. For method using linearly increasing tracer include a method attribute: 'linearly increasing tracer'For method using uniform source (1yr/yr) include a method attribute: 'uniform source'

2: Aerosol Optical Depth at 550nm Due to Stratospheric Volcanic Aerosols
4: Aerosol optical depth at 550nm due to stratospheric volcanic aerosols

2: Aragonite Concentration
4: Sum of particulate aragonite components (e.g. Phytoplankton, Detrital, etc.)

2: Surface Aragonite Concentration
4: sum of particulate aragonite components (e.g. Phytoplankton, Detrital, etc.)

2: Grid-Cell Area for Atmospheric Grid Variables
4: For atmospheres with more than 1 mesh (e.g., staggered grids), report areas that apply to surface vertical fluxes of energy.

2: Grid-Cell Area for Ice Sheet Variables
4: Area of the target grid (not the interpolated area of the source grid).

2: Grid-Cell Area for Ocean Variables
4: Horizontal area of ocean grid cells

2: Grid-Cell Area for River Model Variables
4: For river routing model, if grid differs from the atmospheric grid.

2: Aerodynamic Resistance
4: The 'aerodynamic_resistance' is the resistance to mixing through the boundary layer toward the surface by means of the dominant process, turbulent transport. Reference: Wesely, M. L., 1989,  doi:10.1016/0004-6981(89)90153-4.

2: Bacterial Carbon Concentration
4: Sum of bacterial carbon component concentrations

2: Surface Bacterial Carbon Concentration
4: Sum of bacterial carbon component concentrations

2: Bare Soil Percentage Area Coverage
4: Percentage of entire grid cell  that is covered by bare soil.

2: Region Selection Index
4: A variable with the standard name of region contains strings which indicate geographical regions. These strings must be chosen from the standard region list.

2: Rate of Change of Alkalinity Due to Biological Activity
4: Net total of biological terms in time rate of change of alkalinity

2: Rate of Change of Dissolved Inorganic Carbon Due to Biological Activity
4: Net total of biological terms in time rate of change of dissolved inorganic carbon

2: Rate of Change of Dissolved Inorganic Iron Due to Biological Activity
4: Net total of biological terms in time rate of change of dissolved inorganic iron

2: Rate of Change of Nitrogen Nutrient Due to Biological Activity
4: Net total of biological terms in time rate of change of nitrogen nutrients (e.g. NO3+NH4)

2: Rate of Change of Dissolved Phosphorus Due to Biological Activity
4: Net of biological terms in time rate of change of dissolved phosphate

2: Rate of Change of Dissolved Inorganic Silicon Due to Biological Activity
4: Net of biological terms in time rate of change of dissolved inorganic silicon

2: Mole Concentration of Particulate Organic Matter Expressed as Iron in Sea Water
4: Sum of particulate organic iron component concentrations

2: Surface Mole Concentration of Particulate Organic Matter Expressed as Iron in Sea Water
4: sum of particulate organic iron component concentrations

2: Sea Water Conservative Temperature
4: Sea water conservative temperature (this should be contributed only for models using conservative temperature as prognostic field)

2: Global Average Sea Water Conservative Temperature
4: Diagnostic should be contributed only for models using conservative temperature as prognostic field.

2: Boundary Layer Depth
4: Boundary layer depth

2: Total Inorganic Bromine Volume Mixing Ratio
4: Total family (the sum of all appropriate species in the model) ; list the species in the netCDF header, e.g. Bry = Br + BrO + HOBr + HBr + BrONO2 + BrCl Definition: Total inorganic bromine (e.g., HBr and inorganic bromine oxides and radicals (e.g., BrO, atomic bromine (Br), bromine nitrate (BrONO2)) resulting from degradation of bromine-containing organic source gases (halons, methyl bromide, VSLS), and natural inorganic bromine sources (e.g., volcanoes, sea salt, and other aerosols) add comment attribute with detailed description about how the model calculates these fields

2: Aerosol Backscatter Coefficient
4: Aerosol  Backscatter at 550nm and 180 degrees, computed from extinction and lidar ratio

2: Mole Concentration of Particulate Organic Matter Expressed as Silicon in Sea Water
4: Sum of particulate silica component concentrations

2: Surface Mole Concentration of Particulate Organic Matter Expressed as Silicon in Sea Water
4: sum of particulate silica component concentrations

2: Percentage of Entire Grid cell  that is Covered by Burnt Vegetation (All Classes)
4: Percentage of grid cell burned due to all fires including natural and anthropogenic fires and those associated with anthropogenic Land-use change

2: Mass of 13C in All Terrestrial Carbon Pools
4: Carbon-13 mass content per unit area in vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass), litter (dead plant material in or above the soil), soil, and forestry and agricultural products (e.g. paper, cardboard, furniture, timber for construction, biofuels and food for both humans and livestock).

2: Mass of 13C in Litter Pool
4: Carbon-13 mass content per unit area litter (dead plant material in or above the soil).

2: Mass of 13C in Soil Pool
4: Carbon-13 mass content per unit area in soil.

2: Mass of 13C in Vegetation
4: Carbon-13 mass content per unit area in vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass).

2: Mass of 14C in All Terrestrial Carbon Pools
4: Carbon-14 mass content per unit area in vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass), litter (dead plant material in or above the soil), soil, and forestry and agricultural products (e.g. paper, cardboard, furniture, timber for construction, biofuels and food for both humans and livestock).

2: Mass of 14C in Litter Pool
4: Carbon-14 mass content per unit area litter (dead plant material in or above the soil).

2: Mass of 14C in Soil Pool
4: Carbon-14 mass content per unit area in soil.

2: Mass of 14C in Vegetation
4: Carbon-14 mass content per unit area in vegetation (any living plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass).

2: C2H2 Volume Mixing Ratio
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: C2H6 Volume Mixing Ratio
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: C3H6  volume mixing ratio
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: C3H8  volume mixing ratio
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: Percentage Cover by C3 Plant Functional Type
4: Percentage of entire grid cell  that is covered by C3 PFTs (including grass, crops, and trees).

2: Percentage Cover by C4 Plant Functional Type
4: Percentage of entire grid cell  that is covered by C4 PFTs (including grass and crops).

2: Calcite Concentration
4: Sum of particulate calcite component concentrations (e.g. Phytoplankton, Detrital, etc.)

2: Surface Calcite Concentration
4: sum of particulate calcite component concentrations (e.g. Phytoplankton, Detrital, etc.)

2: Air Pressure at Convective Cloud Base
4: Where convective cloud is present in the grid cell, the instantaneous cloud base altitude should be that of the bottom of the lowest level containing convective cloud. Missing data should be reported in the absence of convective cloud. The time mean should be calculated from these quantities averaging over occasions when convective cloud is present only, and should contain missing data for occasions when no convective cloud is present during the meaning period.

2: Cloud Droplet Number Concentration of Convective Cloud Tops
4: Droplets are liquid only.  Report concentration 'as seen from space' over convective liquid cloudy portion of grid cell.  This is the value from uppermost model layer with liquid cloud or, if available, it is better to sum over all liquid cloud tops, no matter where they occur, as long as they are seen from the top of the atmosphere. Weight by total liquid cloud top fraction of  (as seen from TOA) each time sample when computing monthly mean.

2: Cloud Condensation Nuclei Concentration at Liquid Cloud Top
4: proposed name: number_concentration_of_ambient_aerosol_in_air_at_liquid_water_cloud_top

2: Air Pressure at Convective Cloud Top
4: Where convective cloud is present in the grid cell, the instantaneous cloud top altitude should be that of the top of the highest level containing convective cloud. Missing data should be reported in the absence of convective cloud. The time mean should be calculated from these quantities averaging over occasions when convective cloud is present only, and should contain missing data for occasions when no convective cloud is present during the meaning period.

2: Carbon Mass in Coarse Woody Debris
4: Carbon mass per unit area in woody debris (dead organic matter composed of coarse wood.  It is distinct from litter)

2: Cloud Liquid Droplet Number Concentration
4: Cloud Droplet Number Concentration in liquid water clouds.

2: CloudSat Radar Reflectivity CFAD
4: CFAD (Cloud Frequency Altitude Diagrams) are frequency distributions of radar  reflectivity (or lidar scattering ratio) as a function of altitude. The variable cfadDbze94 is defined as the simulated relative frequency of occurrence of radar reflectivity in sampling volumes defined by altitude bins. The radar is observing at a frequency of 94GHz.

2: CALIPSO Scattering Ratio CFAD
4: CFAD (Cloud Frequency Altitude Diagrams) are frequency distributions of radar  reflectivity (or lidar scattering ratio) as a function of altitude. The variable cfadLidarsr532 is defined as the simulated relative frequency of lidar scattering ratio in sampling volumes defined by altitude bins. The lidar is observing at a wavelength of 532nm.

2: Mole Concentration of CFC11 in Sea Water
4: Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called 'molarity', and is used in the construction 'mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y', where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. The chemical formula of CFC11 is CFCl3. The IUPAC name for CFC11 is trichloro-fluoro-methane.

2: Global Mean Mole Fraction of CFC113
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.  The chemical formula of CFC113 is CCl2FCClF2.  The IUPAC name for CFC113 is 1,1,2-trichloro-1,2,2-trifluoro-ethane.

2: Global Mean Mole Fraction of CFC11
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.  The chemical formula of CFC11 is CFCl3.  The IUPAC name for CFC11 is trichloro-fluoro-methane.

2: Mole Concentration of CFC12 in Sea Water
4: Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called 'molarity', and is used in the construction 'mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y', where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. The chemical formula for CFC12 is CF2Cl2. The IUPAC name for CFC12 is dichloro-difluoro-methane.

2: Global Mean Mole Fraction of CFC12
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.  The chemical formula of CFC12 is CF2Cl2.  The IUPAC name for CFC12 is dichloro-difluoro-methane.

2: CH3COCH3  volume mixing ratio
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction 'mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y', where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. Acetone is an organic molecule with the chemical formula CH3CH3CO. The IUPAC name for acetone is propan-2-one. Acetone is a member of the group of organic compounds known as ketones. There are standard names for the ketone group as well as for some of the individual species.

2: Mole Fraction of CH4
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: Global Mean Mole Fraction of CH4
4: Global Mean Mole Fraction of CH4

2: Aqueous-Phase Production Rate of SO4
4: proposed name: tendency_of_atmosphere_mass_content_of_sulfate_dry_aerosol_due_to_aqueous_phase_net_chemical_production

2: Gas-Phase Production Rate of SO4
4: proposed name: tendency_of_atmosphere_mass_content_of_sulfate_dry_aerosol_due_to_gas_phase_net_chemical_production

2: Total Net Production of Anthropogenic Secondary Organic Aerosol
4: anthropogenic part of chepsoa

2: Chemical Production of Dry Aerosol Secondary Organic Matter
4: If model lumps secondary organic aerosol (SOA) emissions with primary organic aerosol (POA), then the sum of POA and SOA emissions is reported as OA emissions. Here, mass refers to the mass of primary organic matter, not mass of organic carbon alone.

2: Mass Concentration of Total Phytoplankton Expressed as Chlorophyll in Sea Water
4: Sum of chlorophyll from all phytoplankton group concentrations.  In most models this is equal to chldiat+chlmisc, that is the sum of Diatom Chlorophyll Mass Concentration and Other Phytoplankton Chlorophyll Mass Concentration

2: Mass Concentration of Calcareous Phytoplankton Expressed as Chlorophyll in Sea Water
4: chlorophyll concentration from the calcite-producing phytoplankton component alone

2: Surface Mass Concentration of Calcareous Phytoplankton Expressed as Chlorophyll in Sea Water
4: chlorophyll concentration from the calcite-producing phytoplankton component alone

2: Mass Concentration of Diatoms Expressed as Chlorophyll in Sea Water
4: Chlorophyll from diatom phytoplankton component concentration alone

2: Surface Mass Concentration of Diatoms Expressed as Chlorophyll in Sea Water
4: chlorophyll from diatom phytoplankton component concentration alone

2: Mass Concentration of Diazotrophs Expressed as Chlorophyll in Sea Water
4: Chlorophyll concentration from the diazotrophic phytoplankton component alone

2: Surface Mass Concentration of Diazotrophs Expressed as Chlorophyll in Sea Water
4: chlorophyll concentration from the diazotrophic phytoplankton component alone

2: Mass Concentration of Other Phytoplankton Expressed as Chlorophyll in Sea Water
4: Chlorophyll from additional phytoplankton component concentrations alone

2: Surface Mass Concentration of Other Phytoplankton Expressed as Chlorophyll in Sea Water
4: chlorophyll from additional phytoplankton component concentrations alone

2: Surface Mass Concentration of Total Phytoplankton Expressed as Chlorophyll in Sea Water
4: Sum of chlorophyll from all phytoplankton group concentrations at the sea surface.  In most models this is equal to chldiat+chlmisc, that is the sum of 'Diatom Chlorophyll Mass Concentration' plus 'Other Phytoplankton Chlorophyll Mass Concentration'

2: Mass Concentration of Picophytoplankton Expressed as Chlorophyll in Sea Water
4: chlorophyll concentration from the picophytoplankton (<2 um) component alone

2: Surface Mass Concentration of Picophytoplankton Expressed as Chlorophyll in Sea Water
4: chlorophyll concentration from the picophytoplankton (<2 um) component alone

2: Fraction of Time Convection Occurs in Cell
4: Fraction of time that convection occurs in the grid cell.

2: Percentage Cloud Cover
4: Percentage cloud cover, including both large-scale and convective cloud.

2: Total Carbon in All Terrestrial Carbon Pools
4: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

2: Clay Fraction
4: 'Volume fraction' is used in the construction volume_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: Convective Cloud Area Percentage
4: Include only convective cloud.

2: CALIPSO Percentage Cloud Cover
4: Percentage cloud cover in CALIPSO standard atmospheric layers.

2: CALIPSO Cloud Cover Percentage Undetected by CloudSat (as Percentage of Area Covered)
4: Clouds detected by CALIPSO but below the detectability threshold of CloudSat

2: CALIPSO Ice Cloud Percentage
4: Percentage cloud cover in CALIPSO standard atmospheric layers.

2: CALIPSO Liquid Cloud Percentage
4: Percentage liquid water ice cloud cover in CALIPSO standard atmospheric layers.

2: Cloud Ice Mixing Ratio
4: Cloud ice mixing ratio

2: Ice Crystal Number Concentration of Cloud Tops
4: Concentration 'as seen from space' over ice-cloud portion of grid cell.  This is the value from uppermost model layer with ice cloud or, if available, it is the sum over all ice cloud tops, no matter where they occur, as long as they are seen from the top of the atmosphere. Weight by total ice cloud top fraction (as seen from TOA) of each time sample when computing monthly mean.

2: Cloud Droplet Number Concentration of Cloud Tops
4: Droplets are liquid only.  Report concentration 'as seen from space' over liquid cloudy portion of grid cell.  This is the value from uppermost model layer with liquid cloud or, if available, it is better to sum over all liquid cloud tops, no matter where they occur, as long as they are seen from the top of the atmosphere. Weight by total liquid cloud top fraction of  (as seen from TOA) each time sample when computing monthly mean.

2: Column Integrated Cloud Droplet Number
4: Droplets are liquid only.  Values are weighted by liquid cloud fraction in each layer when vertically integrating, and for monthly means the samples are weighted by total liquid cloud fraction (as seen from TOA).

2: Cloud Water Mixing Ratio
4: Cloud water mixing ratio

2: Carbon Mass in Leaves
4: Carbon mass per unit area in leaves.

2: CALIPSO High Level Cloud Area Percentage
4: Percentage cloud cover in layer centred on 220hPa

2: Mass Fraction of Cloud Ice
4: Includes both large-scale and convective cloud. This is calculated as the mass of cloud ice in the grid cell divided by the mass of air (including the water in all phases) in the grid cell. It includes precipitating hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

2: Mass Fraction of Convective Cloud Ice
4: Calculated as the mass of convective cloud ice  in the grid cell divided by the mass of air (including the water in all phases) in the grid cell.  This includes precipitating hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

2: MODIS Ice Cloud Area Percentage
4: Total ice cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen by the  Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS).

2: Mass Fraction of Stratiform Cloud Ice
4: Calculated as the mass of stratiform cloud ice  in the grid cell divided by the mass of air (including the water in all phases) in the grid cell.  This includes precipitating hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

2: ISCCP Cloud Area Percentage
4: Percentage cloud cover in optical depth categories.

2: Carbon Mass in Litter Pool
4: 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The sum of the quantities with standard names surface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon has the standard name litter_mass_content_of_carbon.

2: Carbon Mass in Above-Ground Litter
4: 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. 'Surface litter' means the part of the litter resting above the soil surface. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The sum of the quantities with standard names surface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon has the standard name litter_mass_content_of_carbon.

2: Carbon Mass in Below-Ground Litter
4: 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. 'subsurface litter' means the part of the litter mixed within the soil below the surface. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The sum of the quantities with standard names surface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon has the standard name litter_mass_content_of_carbon.

2: Carbon Mass in Coarse Woody Debris
4: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. 'Wood debris' means dead organic matter composed of coarse wood. It is distinct from fine litter. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent.

2: Carbon Mass in Litter on Grass Tiles
4: 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The sum of the quantities with standard names surface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon has the standard name litter_mass_content_of_carbon.

2: Carbon  in Above and Below-Ground Litter Pools on Land-Use Tiles
4: end of year values (not annual mean)

2: Carbon Mass in Litter on Shrub Tiles
4: 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The sum of the quantities with standard names surface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon has the standard name litter_mass_content_of_carbon.

2: Carbon Mass in Below-Ground Litter
4: subsurface litter pool fed by root inputs.

2: Carbon Mass in Above-Ground Litter
4: Surface or near-surface litter pool fed by leaf and above-ground litterfall

2: Carbon Mass in Litter on Tree Tiles
4: 'Litter' is dead plant material in or above the soil. It is distinct from coarse wood debris. The precise distinction between 'fine' and 'coarse' is model dependent. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The sum of the quantities with standard names surface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon and subsurface_litter_mass_content_of_carbon has the standard name litter_mass_content_of_carbon.

2: Ice Water Path
4: mass of ice water in the column divided by the area of the column (not just the area of the cloudy portion of the column). Includes precipitating frozen hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeor affects the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

2: Convective Ice Water Path
4: calculate mass of convective ice water in the column divided by the area of the column (not just the area of the cloudy portion of the column). This includes precipitating frozen hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

2: CALIPSO Low Level Cloud Cover Percentage
4: Percentage cloud cover in layer centred on 840hPa

2: CALIPSO Mid Level Cloud Cover Percentage
4: Percentage cloud cover in layer centred on 560hPa

2: Percentage Cloud Cover as Calculated by the MISR Simulator (Including Error Flag)
4: Cloud percentage in spectral bands and layers as observed by the Multi-angle Imaging SpectroRadiometer (MISR) instrument. The first layer in each profile is reserved for a retrieval error flag.

2: Percentage Cover of Stratiform Cloud
4: Cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column due to stratiform clouds, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.

2: Total Cloud Cover Percentage
4: Total cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.

2: Convective Cloud Cover Percentage
4: Convective cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Includes only convective cloud.

2: CALIPSO Total Cloud Cover Percentage
4: Total cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen by the  Cloud-Aerosol Lidar and Infrared Pathfinder Satellite Observation (CALIPSO) instrument. Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.

2: ISCCP Total Cloud Cover Percentage
4: Total cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen by the International Satellite Cloud Climatology Project (ISCCP) analysis. Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.  (MODIS). Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.

2: MODIS Total Cloud Cover Percentage
4: Total cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen by the  Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS). Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.

2: Mass Fraction of Cloud Liquid Water
4: Includes both large-scale and convective cloud. Calculate as the mass of cloud liquid water in the grid cell divided by the mass of air (including the water in all phases) in the grid cells. Precipitating hydrometeors are included ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

2: Mass Fraction of Convective Cloud Liquid Water
4: Calculated as the mass of convective cloud liquid water in the grid cell divided by the mass of air (including the water in all phases) in the grid cell.  This includes precipitating hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

2: MODIS Liquid Cloud Percentage
4: Mass of cloud liquid water, as seen by the  Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS). Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.

2: Mass Fraction of Stratiform Cloud Liquid Water
4: Calculated as the mass of stratiform cloud liquid water in the grid cell divided by the mass of air (including the water in all phases) in the grid cell.  This includes precipitating hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

2: Condensed Water Path
4: Mass of condensed (liquid + ice) water in the column divided by the area of the column (not just the area of the cloudy portion of the column). Includes precipitating hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

2: Convective Condensed Water Path
4: calculate mass of convective condensed (liquid + ice) water in the column divided by the area of the column (not just the area of the cloudy portion of the column). This includes precipitating hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

2: Total Inorganic Chlorine Volume Mixing Ratio
4: Total family (the sum of all appropriate species in the model) ; list the species in the netCDF header, e.g. Cly = HCl + ClONO2 + HOCl + ClO + Cl + 2*Cl2O2 +2Cl2 + OClO + BrCl Definition: Total inorganic stratospheric chlorine (e.g., HCl, ClO) resulting from degradation of chlorine-containing source gases (CFCs, HCFCs, VSLS), and natural inorganic chlorine sources (e.g., sea salt and other aerosols) add comment attribute with detailed description about how the model calculates these fields

2: Carbon Mass in Other Living Compartments on Land
4: e.g., labile, fruits, reserves, etc.

2: Canopy Covered Area Percentage
4: Percentage of area covered by vegetation.

2: CO Volume Mixing Ratio
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: Mole Fraction of CO2
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: 3D-Field of Transported CO2
4: report 3D field of model simulated atmospheric CO2 mass mixing ration on model levels

2: Total Atmospheric Mass of CO2
4: Total atmospheric mass of Carbon Dioxide

2: Atmosphere CO2
4: As co2, but only at the surface

2: Carbonate Ion Concentration
4: Mole concentration (number of moles per unit volume: molarity) of the carbonate anion (CO3).

2: Abiotic Carbonate Ion Concentration
4: Mole concentration (number of moles per unit volume: molarity) of the abiotic-analogue carbonate anion (CO3). An abiotic analogue is used to simulate the effect on a modelled variable when biological effects on ocean carbon concentration and alkalinity are ignored.

2: Surface Abiotic Carbonate Ion Concentration
4: Near surface mole concentration (number of moles per unit volume: molarity) of the abiotic-analogue carbonate anion (CO3). An abiotic analogue is used to simulate the effect on a modelled variable when biological effects on ocean carbon concentration and alkalinity are ignored.

2: Natural Carbonate Ion Concentration
4: Surface mole concentration (number of moles per unit volume: molarity) of the natural-analogue carbonate anion (CO3). A natural analogue is used to simulate the effect on a modelled variable of imposing preindustrial atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations, even when the model as a whole may be subjected to varying forcings.

2: Surface Natural Carbonate Ion Concentration
4: Near surface mole concentration (number of moles per unit volume: molarity) of the natural-analogue carbonate anion (CO3). A natural analogue is used to simulate the effect on a modelled variable of imposing preindustrial atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations, even when the model as a whole may be subjected to varying forcings.

2: Surface Carbonate Ion Concentration
4: Near surface mole concentration (number of moles per unit volume: molarity) of the carbonate anion (CO3).

2: Mole Concentration of Carbonate Ion in Equilibrium with Pure Aragonite in Sea Water
4: Mole concentration (number of moles per unit volume: molarity) of the carbonate anion (CO3) for sea water in equilibrium with pure Aragonite. Aragonite  (CaCO3) is a mineral that is a polymorph of calcium carbonate.

2: Surface Mole Concentration of Carbonate Ion in Equilibrium with Pure Aragonite in Sea Water
4: Near surface mole concentration (number of moles per unit volume: molarity) of the carbonate anion (CO3) for sea water in equilibrium with pure Aragonite. Aragonite  (CaCO3) is a mineral that is a polymorph of calcium carbonate.

2: Mole Concentration of Carbonate Ion in Equilibrium with Pure Calcite in Sea Water
4: Mole concentration (number of moles per unit volume: molarity) of the carbonate anion (CO3) for sea water in equilibrium with pure calcite. Aragonite  (CaCO3) is a mineral that is a polymorph of calcium carbonate.

2: Surface Mole Concentration of Carbonate Ion in Equilibrium with Pure Calcite in Sea Water
4: Near surface mole concentration (number of moles per unit volume: molarity) of the carbonate anion (CO3) for sea water in equilibrium with pure calcite. Aragonite  (CaCO3) is a mineral that is a polymorph of calcium carbonate.

2: Cloud Optical Depth
4: The optical thickness is the integral along the path of radiation of a volume scattering/absorption/attenuation coefficient. The radiative flux is reduced by a factor exp(-optical_thickness) on traversing the path. A coordinate variable of radiation_wavelength or radiation_frequency can be specified to indicate that the optical thickness applies at specific wavelengths or frequencies. The atmosphere optical thickness applies to radiation passing through the entire atmosphere. 'Cloud' means the component of extinction owing to the presence of liquid or ice water particles. The specification of a physical process by the phrase due_to_process means that the quantity named is a  single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase.

2: Column Integrated Mass Flux
4: Column integral of (mcu-mcd)

2: Number Concentration Coarse Mode Aerosol
4: includes all particles with diameter larger than 1 micron

2: Aerosol Number Concentration
4: 'Number concentration' means the number of particles or other specified objects per unit volume. 'Aerosol' means the system of suspended liquid or solid particles in air (except cloud droplets) and their carrier gas, the air itself. 'Ambient_aerosol' means that the aerosol is measured or modelled at the ambient state of pressure, temperature and relative humidity that exists in its immediate environment. 'Ambient aerosol particles' are aerosol particles that have taken up ambient water through hygroscopic growth. The extent of hygroscopic growth depends on the relative humidity and the composition of the particles.

2: Concentration of Dust
4: Mass concentration means mass per unit volume and is used in the construction mass_concentration_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. 'Aerosol' means the system of suspended liquid or solid particles in air (except cloud droplets) and their carrier gas, the air itself. Aerosol particles take up ambient water (a process known as hygroscopic growth) depending on the relative humidity and the composition of the particles. 'Dry aerosol particles' means aerosol particles without any water uptake.

2: Number Concentration of Nucleation Mode Aerosol
4: includes all particles with diameter smaller than 3 nm

2: Carbon Mass in Vegetation Components Other than Leaves, Stems and Roots
4: E.g. fruits, seeds, etc.

2: Carbon Mass in Products of Land-Use Change
4: Carbon mass per unit area in that has been removed from the environment through  land use change.

2: Wood and Agricultural Product Pool Carbon Associated with Land-Use Tiles
4: Anthropogenic pools associated with land use tiles into which harvests and cleared carbon are deposited before release into atmosphere PLUS any remaining anthropogenic pools that may be associated with lands which were converted into land use tiles during reported period. Examples of products include paper, cardboard, timber for construction, and crop harvest for food or fuel. Does NOT include residue which is deposited into soil or litter; end of year values (not annual mean).

2: Carbon Mass in Roots
4: Carbon mass per unit area in roots, including fine and coarse roots.

2: Percentage Crop Cover
4: Percentage of entire grid cell  that is covered by crop.

2: Percentage Cover by C3 Crops
4: Percentage of entire grid cell covered by C3 crops

2: Percentage Cover by C4 Crops
4: Percentage of entire grid cell covered by C4 crops

2: Carbon Mass in Model Soil Pool
4: Carbon mass in the full depth of the soil model.

2: Carbon Mass in Soil Pool Above 1m Depth
4: Report missing data over ocean grid cells. For fractional land report value averaged over the land fraction.

2: Carbon Mass in Fast Soil Pool
4: Carbon mass per unit area in fast soil pool. Fast means a lifetime of less than 10 years for reference climate conditions (20th century) in the absence of water limitations.

2: Carbon Mass in Soil on Grass Tiles
4: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The 'soil content' of a quantity refers to the vertical integral from the surface down to the bottom of the soil model. For the content between specified levels in the soil, standard names including content_of_soil_layer are used.

2: Carbon Mass in Each Model Soil Level (Summed over All Soil Carbon Pools in That Level)
4: for models with vertically discretised soil carbon, report total soil carbon for each level

2: carbon  in soil pool on Land-use tiles
4: end of year values (not annual mean)

2: Carbon Mass in Medium Soil Pool
4: Carbon mass per unit area in medium (rate) soil pool. Medium means a lifetime of more than than 10 years and less than 100 years for reference climate conditions (20th century) in the absence of water limitations.

2: Carbon Mass in Each Model Soil Pool (Summed over Vertical Levels)
4: For models with multiple soil carbon pools, report each pool here. If models also have vertical discretisation these should be aggregated

2: Carbon Mass in Soil on Shrub Tiles
4: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The 'soil content' of a quantity refers to the vertical integral from the surface down to the bottom of the soil model. For the content between specified levels in the soil, standard names including content_of_soil_layer are used.

2: Carbon Mass in Slow Soil Pool
4: Carbon mass per unit area in slow soil pool. Slow means a lifetime of more than 100 years for reference climate (20th century) in the absence of water limitations.

2: Carbon Mass in Soil on Tree Tiles
4: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The 'soil content' of a quantity refers to the vertical integral from the surface down to the bottom of the soil model. For the content between specified levels in the soil, standard names including content_of_soil_layer are used.

2: Carbon Mass in Stem
4: including sapwood and hardwood.

2: Total Carbon Loss from Natural and Managed Fire on Land-Use Tile, Including Deforestation Fires [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: Different from LMON this flux should include all fires occurring on the land use tile, including natural, man-made and deforestation fires

2: Carbon Mass in Vegetation
4: Carbon mass per unit area in vegetation.

2: Carbon Mass in Vegetation on Grass Tiles
4: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. 'Vegetation' means any plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass. Plants are autotrophs i.e. 'producers' of biomass using carbon obtained from carbon dioxide.

2: Carbon in Vegetation on Land-Use Tiles
4: end of year values (not annual mean)

2: Carbon Mass in Vegetation on Shrub Tiles
4: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. 'Vegetation' means any plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass. Plants are autotrophs i.e. 'producers' of biomass using carbon obtained from carbon dioxide.

2: Carbon Mass in Vegetation on Tree Tiles
4: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. 'Vegetation' means any plants e.g. trees, shrubs, grass. Plants are autotrophs i.e. 'producers' of biomass using carbon obtained from carbon dioxide.

2: Total Canopy Water Storage
4: 'Amount' means mass per unit area. 'Water' means water in all phases, including frozen i.e. ice and snow. 'Canopy' means the plant or vegetation canopy. The canopy water is the water on the canopy.

2: Carbon Mass in Wood
4: Carbon mass per unit area in wood, including sapwood and hardwood.

2: Aragonite Dissolution
4: Rate of change of Aragonite carbon mole concentration  due to dissolution

2: Calcite Dissolution
4: Rate of change of Calcite carbon mole concentration  due to dissolution

2: Change in Interception Storage
4: The phrase 'change_over_time_in_X' means change in a quantity X over a time-interval, which should be defined by the bounds of the time coordinate. 'Canopy' means the plant or vegetation canopy. Canopy water is the water on the canopy. 'Water' means water in all phases, including frozen, i.e. ice and snow. 'Amount' means mass per unit area.

2: Convective Cloud Emissivity
4: This is the in-cloud emissivity obtained by considering only the cloudy portion of the grid cell.

2: Stratiform Cloud Emissivity
4: This is the in-cloud emissivity obtained by considering only the cloudy portion of the grid cell.

2: Total Deposition Rate of Dust
4: Fdry mass deposition rate of dust

2: Sea Floor Depth Below Geoid
4: Ocean bathymetry.   Reported here is the sea floor depth for present day relative to z=0 geoid. Reported as missing for land grid cells.

2: Detrital Organic Carbon Concentration
4: Sum of detrital organic carbon component concentrations

2: Surface Detrital Organic Carbon Concentration
4: sum of detrital organic carbon component concentrations

2: Dissolved Iron Concentration
4: Dissolved iron in sea water,  including both Fe2+ and Fe3+ ions (but not particulate detrital iron)

2: Surface Dissolved Iron Concentration
4: dissolved iron in sea water is meant to include both Fe2+ and Fe3+ ions (but not, e.g., particulate detrital iron)

2: Change in Groundwater
4: Groundwater is subsurface water below the depth of the water table.

2: Tendency of Eastward Wind from Numerical Artefacts
4: Other sub-grid scale/numerical zonal drag excluding that already provided for the parameterized orographic and non-orographic gravity waves. This would be used to calculate the total 'diabatic drag'. Contributions to this additional drag such Rayleigh friction and diffusion that can be calculated from the monthly mean wind fields should not be included, but details (e.g. coefficients) of the friction and/or diffusion used in the model should be provided separately.

2: Ocean Momentum XY Biharmonic Diffusivity
4: Lateral biharmonic viscosity applied to the momentum equations.

2: Ocean Momentum XY Laplacian Diffusivity
4: Lateral Laplacian viscosity applied to the momentum equations.

2: Ocean Tracer Bolus Biharmonic Diffusivity
4: Parameterized mesoscale eddy advection occurs on a spatial scale of many tens of kilometres and an evolutionary time of weeks(sometimes called bolus advection). Reference: James C. McWilliams 2016, Submesoscale currents in the ocean, Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences, volume 472, issue 2189. DOI: 10.1098/rspa.2016.0117.

2: Ocean Tracer Diffusivity Due to Parameterized Mesoscale Advection
4: Ocean tracer diffusivity associated with parameterized eddy-induced advective transport. Sometimes this diffusivity is called the 'thickness' diffusivity. For CMIP5, this diagnostic was called 'ocean tracer bolus laplacian diffusivity'.  The CMIP6 name is physically more relevant.

2: Ocean Tracer Epineutral Biharmonic Diffusivity
4: Epineutral diffusivity means a lateral diffusivity along a either a neutral or isopycnal density surface due to motion which is not resolved on the grid scale of an ocean model. The type of density surface is dependent on the model formulation.

2: Ocean Tracer Epineutral Laplacian Diffusivity
4: Ocean tracer diffusivity associated with parameterized eddy-induced diffusive transport oriented along neutral or isopycnal directions. Sometimes this diffusivity is called the neutral diffusivity or isopycnal diffusivity or Redi diffusivity.

2: Ocean Tracer XY Biharmonic Diffusivity
4: Diffusivity is also sometimes known as the coefficient of diffusion. Diffusion occurs as a result of a gradient in the spatial distribution of mass concentration, temperature or momentum.  The diffusivity may be very different in the vertical and horizontal directions. 'xy diffusivity' means the lateral along_coordinate component of diffusivity due to motion which is not resolved on the grid scale of the model.  xy diffusivities are used in some ocean models to counteract the numerical instabilities inherent in certain implementations of rotated neutral diffusion. 'biharmonic diffusivity' means diffusivity for use with a biharmonic diffusion operator.

2: Ocean Tracer XY Laplacian Diffusivity
4: Diffusivity is also sometimes known as the coefficient of diffusion. Diffusion occurs as a result of a gradient in the spatial distribution of mass concentration, temperature or momentum.  The diffusivity may be very different in the vertical and horizontal directions. 'xy diffusivity' means the lateral along_coordinate component of diffusivity due to motion which is not resolved on the grid scale of the model.  xy diffusivities are used in some ocean models to counteract the numerical instabilities inherent in certain implementations of rotated neutral diffusion. 'laplacian diffusivity' means diffusivity for use with a Laplacian diffusion operator.

2: Ocean Vertical Heat Diffusivity
4: Vertical/dianeutral diffusivity applied to prognostic temperature field.

2: Ocean Vertical Momentum Diffusivity Due to Background
4: Vertical/dianeutral diffusivity applied to momentum due to the background (i.e. caused by a time invariant imposed field which may be either constant over the globe or spatially varying, depending on the ocean model used).

2: Ocean Vertical Momentum Diffusivity Due to Form Drag
4: Vertical/dianeutral diffusivity applied to momentum due to form drag (i.e. resulting from a model scheme representing  mesoscale eddy-induced form drag).

2: Ocean Vertical Momentum Diffusivity
4: Vertical/dianeutral diffusivity applied to momentum.

2: Ocean Vertical Momentum Diffusivity Due to Tides
4: Diffusivity is also sometimes known as the coefficient of diffusion. Diffusion occurs as a result of a gradient in the spatial distribution of mass concentration, temperature or momentum.  The diffusivity may be very different in the vertical and horizontal directions. The construction vertical_X_diffusivity means the vertical component of the diffusivity of X due to motion which is not resolved on the grid scale of the model. 'Due to tides' means due to all astronomical gravity changes which manifest as tides. No distinction is made between different tidal components. The specification of a physical process by the phrase due_to_process means that the quantity named is a  single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity  named by omitting the phrase.

2: Ocean Vertical Salt Diffusivity
4: Vertical/dianeutral diffusivity applied to prognostic salinity field.

2: Ocean Vertical Tracer Diffusivity Due to Background
4: Vertical/dianeutral diffusivity applied to tracers due to the background (i.e. caused by a time invariant imposed field which may be either constant over the globe or spatially varying, depending on the ocean model used).

2: Ocean Vertical Tracer Diffusivity Due to Tides
4: Vertical/dianeutral diffusivity applied to tracers due to tides (i.e. caused by astronomical gravity changes which manifest as tides).

2: Ocean Kinetic Energy Dissipation per Unit Area Due to Vertical Friction
4: Friction, leading to the dissipation of kinetic energy, arises in ocean models as a result of the viscosity of sea water.  Generally, the  lateral (xy) viscosity is given a large value to maintain the numerical stability of the model.  In contrast, the vertical viscosity is usually much smaller. The specification of a physical process by the phrase due_to_process means that the quantity named is a  single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity  named by omitting the phrase.

2: Ocean Kinetic Energy Dissipation per Unit Area Due to XY Friction
4: Depth integrated impacts on kinetic energy arising from lateral frictional dissipation associated with Laplacian and/or biharmonic viscosity. For CMIP5, this diagnostic was 3d, whereas the CMIP6 depth integrated diagnostic is sufficient for many purposes and reduces archive requirements.

2: Dissolved Inorganic Carbon-13 Concentration
4: Dissolved inorganic carbon-13 (CO3+HCO3+H2CO3) concentration

2: Surface Dissolved Inorganic Carbon-13 Concentration
4: Near surface dissolved inorganic carbon-13 (CO3+HCO3+H2CO3) concentration

2: Dissolved Inorganic Carbon-14 Concentration
4: Dissolved inorganic carbon-14 (CO3+HCO3+H2CO3) concentration

2: Abiotic Dissolved Inorganic Carbon-14 Concentration
4: Abiotic Dissolved inorganic carbon-14 (CO3+HCO3+H2CO3) concentration

2: Surface Abiotic Dissolved Inorganic Carbon-14 Concentration
4: Abiotic Dissolved inorganic carbon-14 (CO3+HCO3+H2CO3) concentration

2: Dissolved Inorganic Carbon Concentration
4: Dissolved inorganic carbon (CO3+HCO3+H2CO3) concentration

2: Abiotic Dissolved Inorganic Carbon Concentration
4: Abiotic Dissolved inorganic carbon (CO3+HCO3+H2CO3) concentration

2: Surface Abiotic Dissolved Inorganic Carbon Concentration
4: Abiotic Dissolved inorganic carbon (CO3+HCO3+H2CO3) concentration

2: Natural Dissolved Inorganic Carbon Concentration
4: Dissolved inorganic carbon (CO3+HCO3+H2CO3) concentration at preindustrial atmospheric xCO2

2: Surface Natural Dissolved Inorganic Carbon Concentration
4: Dissolved inorganic carbon (CO3+HCO3+H2CO3) concentration at preindustrial atmospheric xCO2

2: Surface Dissolved Inorganic Carbon Concentration
4: Dissolved inorganic carbon (CO3+HCO3+H2CO3) concentration

2: Dissolved Organic Carbon Concentration
4: Sum of dissolved carbon component concentrations explicitly represented (i.e. not ~40 uM refractory unless explicit)

2: Surface Dissolved Organic Carbon Concentration
4: Sum of dissolved carbon component concentrations explicitly represented (i.e. not ~40 uM refractory unless explicit)

2: Deep Convective Mass Flux
4: The net mass flux  represents the difference between the updraft and downdraft components.   This is calculated as the convective mass flux divided by the area of the whole grid cell (not just the area of the cloud).

2: Depth to Soil Thaw
4: Depth from surface to the zero degree isotherm. Above this isotherm T > 0o, and below this line T < 0o. Missing if surface is frozen or if soil is unfrozen at all depths.

2: Dimethyl Sulphide (DMS) Mole Fraction
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: Mole Concentration of Dimethyl Sulphide in Sea Water
4: Mole concentration of dimethyl sulphide in water

2: Surface Mole Concentration of Dimethyl Sulphide in Sea Water
4: Mole concentration of dimethyl sulphide in water in the near surface layer

2: Delta CO2 Partial Pressure
4: Difference in partial pressure of carbon dioxide between sea water and air.  The partial pressure of a dissolved gas in sea water is the partial pressure in air with which it would be in equilibrium.

2: Abiotic Delta Pco Partial Pressure
4: Difference in partial pressure of abiotic-analogue carbon dioxide between sea water and air.  The partial pressure of a dissolved gas in sea water is the partial pressure in air with which it would be in equilibrium. An abiotic analogue is used to simulate the effect on a modelled variable when biological effects on ocean carbon concentration and alkalinity are ignored.

2: Natural Delta CO2 Partial Pressure
4: Difference in partial pressure of natural-analogue carbon dioxide between sea water and air.  The partial pressure of a dissolved gas in sea water is the partial pressure in air with which it would be in equilibrium.  A natural analogue is used to simulate the effect on a modelled variable of imposing preindustrial atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations, even when the model as a whole may be subjected to varying forcings.

2: Delta O2 Partial Pressure
4: The partial pressure of a dissolved gas in sea water is the partial pressure in air with which it would be in equilibrium.  The partial pressure of a gaseous constituent of air is the pressure which it alone would exert with unchanged temperature and number of moles per unit volume.  The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere.

2: Change in River Storage
4: Change over time of the mass of water per unit area in the fluvial system (stream and floodplain).

2: Dry Deposition Rate of Black Carbon Aerosol Mass
4: Dry deposition includes gravitational settling, impact scavenging, and turbulent deposition.

2: Dry Deposition Rate of Dust
4: Dry deposition includes gravitational settling, impact scavenging, and turbulent deposition.

2: Dry Deposition Rate of NH3
4: dry deposition includes gravitational settling, impact scavenging, and turbulent deposition

2: Dry Deposition Rate of NH4
4: dry deposition includes gravitational settling, impact scavenging, and turbulent deposition

2: Dry Deposition Rate of NOy
4: NOy is the sum of all simulated oxidized nitrogen species out of NO, NO2, HNO3, HNO4, NO3 aerosol, NO3(radical), N2O5, PAN, other organic nitrates. Dry deposition includes gravitational settling, impact scavenging, and turbulent deposition.

2: Dry Deposition Rate of O3
4: dry deposition includes gravitational settling, impact scavenging, and turbulent deposition.

2: Dry Deposition Rate of Dry Aerosol Total Organic Matter
4: Tendency of atmosphere mass content of organic dry aerosol due to dry deposition: This is the sum of dry deposition of primary organic aerosol (POA) and dry deposition of secondary organic aerosol (SOA). Here, mass refers to the mass of organic matter, not mass of organic carbon alone.  We recommend a scale factor of POM=1.4*OC, unless your model has more detailed info available. Was called dry_pom in old ACCMIP Excel table. Dry deposition includes gravitational settling, impact scavenging, and turbulent deposition.

2: Dry Deposition Rate of SO2
4: dry deposition includes gravitational settling, impact scavenging, and turbulent deposition

2: Dry Deposition Rate of SO4
4: dry deposition includes gravitational settling, impact scavenging, and turbulent deposition

2: Dry Deposition Rate of Sea-Salt Aerosol
4: Dry deposition includes gravitational settling, impact scavenging, and turbulent deposition.

2: Change in Soil Moisture
4: The phrase 'change_over_time_in_X' means change in a quantity X over a time-interval, which should be defined by the bounds of the time coordinate. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The mass content of water in soil refers to the vertical integral from the surface down to the bottom of the soil model. For the content between specified levels in the soil, standard names including 'content_of_soil_layer' are used. 'Water' means water in all phases.

2: Change in Snow Water Equivalent
4: Change in time of the mass per unit area of ice in glaciers, ice caps, ice sheets and shelves, river and lake ice, any other ice on a land surface, such as frozen flood water, and snow lying on such ice or on the land surface.

2: Change in Surface Water Storage
4: The phrase 'land_water_amount', often known as 'Terrestrial Water Storage', includes: surface liquid water (water in rivers, wetlands, lakes, reservoirs, rainfall intercepted by the canopy); surface ice and snow (glaciers, ice caps, grounded ice sheets not displacing sea water, river and lake ice, other surface ice such as frozen flood water, snow lying on the surface and intercepted by the canopy); subsurface water (liquid and frozen soil water, groundwater).

2: Convective Cloud Optical Depth
4: This is the in-cloud optical depth obtained by considering only the cloudy portion of the grid cell

2: Stratiform Cloud Optical Depth
4: This is the in-cloud optical depth obtained by considering only the cloudy portion of the grid cell.

2: Change in Surface Heat Storage
4: Change in heat storage over the soil layer and the vegetation for which the energy balance is calculated, accumulated over the sampling time interval.

2: Change in Snow and Ice Cold Content
4: Change in cold content over the snow layer for which the energy balance is calculated, accumulated over the sampling time interval. This should also include the energy contained in the liquid water in the snow pack.

2: Interception Evaporation
4: 'Water' means water in all phases. 'Canopy' means the plant or vegetation canopy. Evaporation is the conversion of liquid or solid into vapor. (The conversion of solid alone into vapor is called 'sublimation'.) In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. Unless indicated in the cell_methods attribute, a quantity is assumed to apply to the whole area of each horizontal grid box. Previously, the qualifier where_type was used to specify that the quantity applies only to the part of the grid box of the named type.  Names containing the where_type qualifier are deprecated and newly created data should use the cell_methods attribute to indicate the horizontal area to which the quantity applies.

2: Aerosol Extinction Coefficient
4: Aerosol Extinction at 550nm

2: Eddy Diffusivity Coefficient for Temperature
4: Vertical diffusion coefficient for temperature due to parametrised eddies

2: Total Emission Rate of Anthropogenic CO
4: Anthropogenic  emission of CO.

2: Total Emission Rate of Anthropogenic NOx
4: Store flux as Nitrogen. Anthropogenic fraction. NOx=NO+NO2, Includes agricultural waste burning but no other biomass burning. Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

2: Total Emission Rate of Anthropogenic Organic Aerosol
4: anthropogenic part of emioa

2: Total Emission Rate of Black Carbon Aerosol Mass
4: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

2: Total Emission Rate of Biogenic NMVOC
4: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field._If_ fixed molecular weight of NMVOC is not available in model, please provide in units of kilomole m-2 s-1 (i.e. kg m-2 s-1 as if model NMVOC had molecular weight of 1) and add a comment to your file.

2: Total Emission Rate of CO
4: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

2: Total Emission Rate of DMS
4: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

2: Total Emission Rate of Dust
4: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

2: Total Emission Rate of Isoprene
4: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field

2: Layer-Integrated Lightning Production of NOx
4: Integrate the NOx production for lightning over model layer. proposed name: tendency_of_atmosphere_mass_content_of_nox_from_lightning

2: Total Emission Rate of NH3
4: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

2: Total Emission Rate of NOx
4: NOx=NO+NO2. Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

2: Primary Emission and Chemical Production of Dry Aerosol Organic Matter
4: This is the sum of total emission of primary organic aerosol (POA) and total production of secondary organic aerosol (SOA) (emipoa+chepsoa). Here, mass refers to the mass of organic matter, not mass of organic carbon alone. We recommend a scale factor of POM=1.4*OC, unless your model has more detailed info available.  Integrate 3D chemical production and emission field vertically to 2d field.

2: Total Emission Rate of SO2
4: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

2: Total Direct Emission Rate of SO4
4: Direct primary emission does not include secondary sulfate production. Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

2: Total Emission Rate of Sea-Salt Aerosol
4: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

2: Total Emission Rate of NMVOC
4: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field. _If_ fixed molecular weight of NMVOC is not available in model, please provide in units of kilomole m-2 s-1 (i.e. kg m-2 s-1 as if model NMVOC had molecular weight of 1) and add a comment to your file.

2: Open Water Evaporation
4: Evaporation (conversion of liquid or solid into vapor) from open water.

2: Downward Flux of Aragonite
4: The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid. Aragonite is a mineral that is a polymorph of calcium carbonate. The chemical formula of aragonite is CaCO3. Standard names also exist for calcite, another polymorph of calcium carbonate.

2: Downward Flux of Particulate Organic Carbon
4: The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.

2: Downward Flux of Calcite
4: The phrase 'expressed_as' is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid. Calcite is a mineral that is a polymorph of calcium carbonate. The chemical formula of calcite is CaCO3. Standard names also exist for aragonite, another polymorph of calcium carbonate.

2: Downward Flux of Particulate Iron
4: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.

2: Northward Component of the Eliassen-Palm Flux
4: Transformed Eulerian Mean Diagnostics Meridional component Fy of Eliassen-Palm (EP) flux (Fy, Fz) derived from 6hr or higher frequency fields (use daily fields or 12 hr fields if the 6 hr are not available). Please use the definitions given by equation 3.5.3a of Andrews, Holton and Leovy text book, but scaled by density to have units m3 s-2.

2: Upward Component of the Eliassen-Palm Flux
4: Transformed Eulerian Mean Diagnostics Meridional component Fz of the Eliassen-Palm (EP) flux (Fy, Fz) derived from 6hr or higher frequency fields (use daily fields or 12 hr fields if the 6 hr are not available). Please use the definitions given by equation 3.5.3b of Andrews, Holton and Leovy text book, but scaled by density to have units m3 s-2.

2: Downward Flux of Particulate Nitrogen
4: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.

2: Downward Flux of Particulate Phosphorus
4: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.

2: Downward Flux of Particulate Silicon
4: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.

2: Bare Soil Evaporation
4: Water here means water in all phases. Evaporation is the conversion of liquid or solid into vapor. (The conversion of solid alone into vapor is called 'sublimation'.) In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

2: Snow Evaporation
4: Water here means water in all phases. Evaporation is the conversion of liquid or solid into vapor. (The conversion of solid alone into vapor is called 'sublimation'.) In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. Unless indicated in the cell_methods attribute, a quantity is assumed to apply to the whole area of each horizontal grid box. Previously, the qualifier where_type was used to specify that the quantity applies only to the part of the grid box of the named type.  Names containing the where_type qualifier are deprecated and newly created data should use the cell_methods attribute to indicate the horizontal area to which the quantity applies.

2: Water Evaporation Flux Where Ice Free Ocean over Sea
4: computed as the total mass of water vapor evaporating from the ice-free portion of the ocean  divided by the area of the ocean portion of the grid cell.

2: Evaporation Including Sublimation and Transpiration
4: Evaporation at surface (also known as evapotranspiration): flux of water into the atmosphere due to conversion of both liquid and solid phases to vapor (from underlying surface and vegetation)

2: Potential Evapotranspiration
4: at surface; potential flux of water into the atmosphere due to conversion of both liquid and solid phases to vapor (from underlying surface and vegetation)

2: Water Evaporation from Soil
4: Water evaporation from soil (including sublimation).

2: Evaporation from Canopy
4: The canopy evaporation and sublimation (if present in model); may include dew formation as a negative flux.

2: Eddy Viscosity Coefficient for Momentum
4: Vertical diffusion coefficient for momentum due to parametrised eddies

2: Downward Flux of Aragonite
4: Downward flux of Aragonite

2: Downward Flux of Particulate Organic Carbon
4: Downward flux of particulate organic carbon

2: Downward Flux of Calcite
4: Downward flux of Calcite

2: Sinking Particulate Iron Flux
4: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.

2: Sinking Particulate Organic Nitrogen Flux
4: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.

2: Sinking Particulate Organic Phosphorus Flux
4: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.

2: Sinking Particulate Silicon Flux
4: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.   'Sinking' is the gravitational settling of particulate matter suspended in a liquid. A sinking flux is positive downwards and is calculated relative to the movement of the surrounding fluid.

2: Anthropogenic Heat Flux Generated from non-Renewable Human Primary Energy Consumption
4: Anthropogenic heat flux generated from non-renewable human primary energy consumption, including energy use by vehicles, commercial and residential buildings, industry, and power plants.  Primary energy refers to energy in natural resources, fossil and nonfossil, before conversion into other forms, such as electricity.

2: Carbon Mass Flux from Vegetation, Litter or Soil Pools into the Atmosphere Due to any Human Activity [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: Anthropogenic flux of carbon as carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. That is, emissions influenced, caused, or created by human activity. Anthropogenic emission of carbon dioxide includes fossil fuel use, cement production, agricultural burning and sources associated with anthropogenic land use change, except forest regrowth.

2: Rate of Change of Biological Alkalinity Due to Biological Activity
4: vertical integral of net biological terms in time rate of change of alkalinity

2: Rate of Change of Dissolved Inorganic Carbon Due to Biological Activity
4: vertical integral of net biological terms in time rate of change of dissolved inorganic carbon

2: Rate of Change of Dissolved Inorganic Iron Due to Biological Activity
4: vertical integral of net biological terms in time rate of change of dissolved inorganic iron

2: Rate of Change of Dissolved Inorganic Nitrogen Due to Biological Activity
4: vertical integral of net biological terms in time rate of change of nitrogen nutrients (e.g. NO3+NH4)

2: Rate of Change of Dissolved Inorganic Phosphorus Due to Biological Activity
4: vertical integral of net biological terms in time rate of change of phosphate

2: Rate of Change of Dissolved Inorganic Silicon Due to Biological Activity
4: vertical integral of net biological terms in time rate of change of dissolved inorganic silicate

2: Biological Nitrogen Fixation
4: The fixation (uptake of nitrogen gas directly from the atmosphere) of nitrogen due to biological processes.

2: Lateral Transfer of Carbon out of Grid Cell That Eventually Goes into Ocean
4: leached carbon etc that goes into run off or river routing and finds its way into ocean should be reported here.

2: Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere Due to All Anthropogenic Emissions of CO2 [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: This is requested only for the emission-driven coupled carbon climate model runs.  Does not include natural fire sources but, includes all anthropogenic sources, including fossil fuel use, cement production, agricultural burning, and sources associated with anthropogenic land use change excluding forest regrowth.

2: Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere Due to Fossil Fuel Emissions of CO2 [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: This is the prescribed anthropogenic CO2 flux from fossil fuel use, including cement production, and flaring (but not from land-use changes, agricultural burning, forest regrowth, etc.)

2: Surface Carbon Mass Flux into the Atmosphere Due to Natural Sources [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: This is what the atmosphere sees (on its own grid).  This field should be equivalent to the combined natural fluxes of carbon  that account for natural exchanges between the atmosphere and land (nep) or ocean (fgco2) reservoirs.

2: Rate of Change of Total Alkalinity
4: vertical integral of net time rate of change of alkalinity

2: Rate of Change of Net Dissolved Inorganic Carbon
4: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area.  'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time. 'Dissolved inorganic carbon' describes a family of chemical species in solution, including carbon dioxide, carbonic acid and the carbonate and bicarbonate anions. 'Dissolved inorganic carbon' is the term used in standard names for all species belonging to the family that are represented within a given model. The list of individual species that are included in a quantity having a group chemical standard name can vary between models.  Where possible, the data variable should be accompanied by a complete description of the species represented, for example, by using a comment attribute.

2: Rate of Change of Net Dissolved Inorganic Iron
4: vertical integral of net time rate of change of dissolved inorganic iron

2: Rate of Change of Net Dissolved Inorganic Nitrogen
4: Net time rate of change of nitrogen nutrients (e.g. NO3+NH4)

2: Rate of Change of Net Dissolved Inorganic Phosphorus
4: vertical integral of net  time rate of change of phosphate

2: Rate of Change of Net Dissolved Inorganic Silicon
4: vertical integral of net time rate of change of dissolved inorganic silicate

2: Deforested Biomass That Goes into Atmosphere as a Result of Anthropogenic Land-Use Change [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.

2: Deforested Biomass That Goes into Product Pool as a Result of Anthropogenic Land-Use Change
4: When land use change results in deforestation of natural vegetation (trees or grasslands) then natural biomass is removed. The treatment of deforested biomass differs significantly across models, but it should be straight-forward to compare deforested biomass across models.

2: Particulate Source of Dissolved Iron
4: Dissolution, remineralization and desorption of iron back to the dissolved phase

2: Non-Biogenic Iron Scavenging
4: Dissolved Fe removed through nonbiogenic scavenging onto particles

2: Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere Due to CO2 Emission from Fire Excluding Land-Use Change [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: CO2 emissions (expressed as a carbon mass flux per unit area) from natural fires and human ignition fires as calculated by the fire module of the dynamic vegetation model, but excluding any CO2 flux from fire included in fLuc (CO2 Flux to Atmosphere from Land Use Change).

2: Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere Due to CO2 Emission from Fire Including All Sources [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: From all sources,  Including natural, anthropogenic and Land-use change. Only total fire emissions can be compared to observations.

2: Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere Due to CO2 Emission from Natural Fire [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: CO2 emissions from natural fires

2: Surface Downward Mass Flux of Carbon-13 as 13CO2 [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: Gas exchange flux of carbon-13 as CO2 (positive into ocean)

2: Surface Downward Mass Flux of Carbon-14 as 14CO2 [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: Gas exchange flux of carbon-14 as CO2 (positive into ocean)

2: Surface Downward Mass Flux of Carbon-14 as Abiotic 14CO2 [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: Gas exchange flux of abiotic 14CO2 (positive into ocean)

2: Surface Downward CFC11 Flux
4: gas exchange flux of CFC11

2: Surface Downward CFC12 Flux
4: gas exchange flux of CFC12

2: Surface Downward Mass Flux of Carbon as CO2 [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: Gas exchange flux of CO2 (positive into ocean)

2: Surface Downward Mass Flux of Carbon as Abiotic CO2 [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: Gas exchange flux of abiotic CO2 (positive into ocean)

2: Surface Downward Mass Flux of Carbon as Natural CO2 [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: Gas exchange flux of natural CO2 (positive into ocean)

2: Surface Upward Flux of DMS
4: Gas exchange flux of DMS (positive into atmosphere)

2: Surface Downward Flux of O2
4: Gas exchange flux of O2 (positive into ocean)

2: Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere Due to Grazing on Land [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: Carbon mass flux per unit area due to grazing on land

2: Surface Downward SF6 Flux
4: gas exchange flux of SF6

2: Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere Due to Crop Harvesting [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: Carbon mass flux per unit area due to crop harvesting

2: Harvested Biomass That Goes Straight into Atmosphere as Carbon Mass Flux [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: any harvested carbon that is assumed to decompose immediately into the atmosphere is reported here

2: Harvested Biomass That Goes into Product Pool
4: be it food or wood harvest, any carbon that is subsequently stored is reported here

2: Water Flux into Sea Water from Icebergs
4: computed as the iceberg melt water  flux into the ocean divided by the area of the ocean portion of the grid cell.

2: Water Flux into Sea Water from Land Ice
4: Computed as the water flux into the ocean due to land ice (runoff water from surface and base of land ice or melt from base of ice shelf or vertical ice front) into the ocean divided by the area ocean portion of the grid cell

2: Lightning Flash Rate
4: proposed name: lightning_flash_rate (units to be interpreted as 'counts km-2 s-1)

2: Field Capacity
4: The field capacity of soil is the maximum content of water it can retain against gravitational drainage. Provide as a percentage of the soil volume.

2: Carbon Mass Flux from Litter, CWD or any non-Living Pool into Atmosphere Due to CO2 Emission from All Fire [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: Required for unambiguous separation of vegetation and soil + litter turnover times, since total fire flux draws from both sources

2: Total Carbon Mass Flux from Litter to Soil
4: Carbon mass flux per unit area into soil from litter (dead plant material in or above the soil).

2: Net Carbon Mass Flux into Atmosphere Due to Land-Use Change [kgC m-2 s-1]
4: Carbon mass flux per unit area into atmosphere due to human changes to land (excluding forest regrowth) accounting possibly for different time-scales related to fate of the wood, for example.
