2: Root Distribution
4: Mass of carbon in roots.

2: Downwelling Shortwave Radiation
4: Downwelling shortwave radiation (includes the fluxes at the surface and top-of-atmosphere)

2: Downwelling Shortwave Radiation 4XCO2 Atmosphere
4: Downwelling shortwave radiation calculated using carbon dioxide concentrations increased fourfold

2: Downwelling Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation
4: Downwelling clear-sky shortwave radiation (includes the fluxes at the surface and top-of-atmosphere)

2: Downwelling Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation 4XCO2 Atmosphere
4: Downwelling clear-sky shortwave radiation calculated using carbon dioxide concentrations increased fourfold

2: Downwelling Clear-Sky, Aerosol-Free Shortwave Radiation
4: Calculated in the absence of aerosols and clouds (following Ghan). This requires a double-call in the radiation code with precisely the same meteorology.

2: Downwelling Clear-Sky, Aerosol-Free, Shortwave Radiation in Bands
4: Calculated in the absence of aerosols and clouds (following Ghan). This requires a double-call in the radiation code with precisely the same meteorology.

2: Downwelling Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation at Each Level for Each Band
4: Calculated with aerosols but without clouds. This is a standard clear-sky calculation

2: Downwelling Shortwave Radiation in Sea Water
4: Downwelling radiation is radiation from above. It does not mean 'net downward'.  When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'.  In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'.  In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.  'shortwave' means shortwave radiation.

2: Net Rate of Absorption of Shortwave Energy in Ocean Layer
4: 'shortwave' means shortwave radiation. 'Layer' means any layer with upper and lower boundaries that have constant values in some vertical coordinate. There must be a vertical coordinate variable indicating the extent of the layer(s). If the layers are model layers, the vertical coordinate can be model_level_number, but it is recommended to specify a physical coordinate (in a scalar or auxiliary coordinate variable) as well. Net absorbed radiation is the difference between absorbed and emitted radiation.

2: Surface Downwelling Shortwave Radiation
4: Surface solar irradiance for UV calculations.

2: Surface Downwelling Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation
4: Surface solar irradiance clear sky for UV calculations

2: Surface Downwelling Clear-Sky, Aerosol-Free Shortwave Radiation
4: Calculated in the absence of aerosols and clouds.

2: Surface Downwelling Clear-Sky, Aerosol-Free Shortwave Radiation in Bands
4: Calculated in the absence of aerosols and clouds, following Ghan (2013, ACP). This requires a double-call in the radiation code with precisely the same meteorology.

2: Surface Downwelling Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation for Each Band
4: Calculated with aerosols but without clouds. This is a standard clear-sky calculation

2: Surface Diffuse Downwelling Clear Sky Shortwave Radiation
4: Surface downwelling solar irradiance from diffuse radiation for UV calculations in clear sky conditions

2: Surface Diffuse Downwelling Shortwave Radiation
4: Surface downwelling solar irradiance from diffuse radiation for UV calculations.

2: Ice Sheet Surface Downwelling Shortwave Radiation
4: Surface solar irradiance for UV calculations

2: TOA Incident Shortwave Radiation
4: Shortwave radiation incident at the top of the atmosphere

2: Net Downward Shortwave Radiation at Sea Water Surface
4: This is the flux into the surface of liquid sea water only. This excludes shortwave flux absorbed by sea ice, but includes any light that passes through the ice and is absorbed by the ocean.

2: Net Shortwave Surface Radiation
4: Net downward shortwave radiation at the surface

2: Upwelling Shortwave Radiation
4: Upwelling shortwave radiation  (includes also the fluxes at the surface and top of atmosphere)

2: Upwelling Shortwave Radiation 4XCO2 Atmosphere
4: Upwelling Shortwave Radiation calculated using carbon dioxide concentrations increased fourfold

2: Upwelling Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation
4: Upwelling clear-sky shortwave radiation  (includes the fluxes at the surface and TOA)

2: Upwelling Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation 4XCO2 Atmosphere
4: Upwelling clear-sky shortwave radiation calculated using carbon dioxide concentrations increased fourfold

2: Upwelling Clear-Sky, Aerosol-Free Shortwave Radiation
4: Calculated in the absence of aerosols and clouds (following Ghan). This requires a double-call in the radiation code with precisely the same meteorology.

2: Upwelling Clear-Sky, Aerosol-Free Shortwave Radiation in Bands
4: Calculated in the absence of aerosols and clouds (following Ghan). This requires a double-call in the radiation code with precisely the same meteorology.

2: Upwelling Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation at Each Level for Each Band
4: Calculated with aerosols but without clouds. This is a standard clear-sky calculation

2: Surface Upwelling Shortwave Radiation
4: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'shortwave' means shortwave radiation. Upwelling radiation is radiation from below. It does not mean 'net upward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

2: Surface Upwelling Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation
4: Surface Upwelling Clear-sky Shortwave Radiation

2: Surface Upwelling Clean Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation
4: Surface Upwelling Clear-sky, Aerosol Free Shortwave Radiation

2: Surface Upwelling Clear-Sky, Aerosol-Free Shortwave Radiation in Bands
4: Calculated in the absence of aerosols and clouds, following Ghan (ACP, 2013). This requires a double-call in the radiation code with precisely the same meteorology.

2: Surface Upwelling Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation for Each Band
4: Calculated with aerosols but without clouds. This is a standard clear-sky calculation

2: Ice Sheet Surface Upwelling Shortwave Radiation
4: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'shortwave' means shortwave radiation. Upwelling radiation is radiation from below. It does not mean 'net upward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

2: Surface Upwelling Shortwave  on Land-use Tile
4: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'shortwave' means shortwave radiation. Upwelling radiation is radiation from below. It does not mean 'net upward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

2: TOA Outgoing Shortwave Radiation
4: at the top of the atmosphere

2: TOA Outgoing Shortwave Radiation in 4XCO2 Atmosphere
4: TOA Outgoing Shortwave Radiation calculated using carbon dioxide concentrations increased fourfold

2: TOA Outgoing Aerosol-Free Shortwave Radiation
4: Flux corresponding to rsut resulting from aerosol-free call to radiation, following Ghan (ACP, 2013)

2: TOA Outgoing Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation
4: Calculated in the absence of clouds.

2: TOA Outgoing Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation 4XCO2 Atmosphere
4: TOA Outgoing Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation calculated using carbon dioxide concentrations increased fourfold

2: TOA Outgoing Clear-Sky, Aerosol-Free Shortwave Radiation
4: Flux corresponding to rsutcs resulting from aerosol-free call to radiation, following Ghan (ACP, 2013)

2: TOA Outgoing Clear-Sky, Aerosol-Free Shortwave Radiation in Bands
4: Calculated in the absence of aerosols and clouds, following Ghan (2013, ACP). This requires a double-call in the radiation code with precisely the same meteorology.

2: TOA Outgoing Clear-Sky Shortwave Radiation for Each Band
4: Calculated with aerosols but without clouds. This is a standard clear-sky calculation

2: Net Downward Radiative Flux at Top of Model
4: Net Downward Radiative Flux at Top of Model : I.e., at the top of that portion of the atmosphere where dynamics are explicitly treated by the model. This is reported only if it differs from the net downward radiative flux at the top of the atmosphere.

2: Relative Vorticity at 850hPa
4: Relative vorticity is the upward component of the vorticity vector i.e. the component which arises from horizontal velocity.

2: Root Zone Soil Moisture
4: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The content of a soil layer is the vertical integral of the specified quantity within the layer. The quantity with standard name mass_content_of_water_in_soil_layer_defined_by_root_depth is the vertical integral between the surface and the depth to which plant roots penetrate. A coordinate variable or scalar coordinate variable with standard name root_depth can be used to specify the extent of the layer. 'Water' means water in all phases.

2: Sand Fraction
4: 'Volume fraction' is used in the construction volume_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: Surface Snow and Ice Sublimation Flux
4: The snow and ice sublimation flux is the loss of snow and ice mass per unit area from the surface resulting from their direct conversion to water vapor that enters the atmosphere.

2: Ice Sheet Surface Snow and Ice Sublimation Flux
4: The snow and ice sublimation flux is the loss of snow and ice mass per unit area from the surface resulting from their direct conversion to water vapor that enters the atmosphere.

2: Sublimation of the Snow Free Area
4: Rate of sublimation of ice into the atmosphere from areas with no snow.

2: Fraction of Time Shallow Convection Occurs
4: Fraction of time that shallow convection occurs in the grid cell.

2: Cloud Droplet Number Concentration of Stratiform Cloud Tops
4: Droplets are liquid only.  Report concentration 'as seen from space' over stratiform liquid cloudy portion of grid cell.  This is the value from uppermost model layer with liquid cloud or, if available, it is better to sum over all liquid cloud tops, no matter where they occur, as long as they are seen from the top of the atmosphere. Weight by total liquid cloud top fraction of  (as seen from TOA) each time sample when computing monthly mean.

2: Surface Concentration of Dust
4: mass concentration of dust dry aerosol in air in model lowest layer

2: Surface Concentration of SO4
4: mass concentration of sulfate dry aerosol in air in model lowest layer.

2: Surface Concentration of Sea-Salt Aerosol
4: mass concentration of sea-salt dry aerosol in air in model lowest layer

2: Sedimentation Flux of Dust Mode Coarse Insoluble
4: Dry mass deposition rate of dust aerosol.

2: Mole Concentration of SF6 in Sea Water
4: Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called 'molarity', and is used in the construction 'mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y', where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. The chemical formula of sulfur hexafluoride is SF6.

2: Near-Surface Wind Speed
4: near-surface (usually, 10 meters) wind speed.

2: Daily Maximum Near-Surface Wind Speed
4: Daily maximum near-surface (usually, 10 meters) wind speed.

2: Downward Sea Ice Basal Salt Flux
4: This field is physical, and it arises since sea ice has a nonzero salt content, so it exchanges salt with the liquid ocean upon melting and freezing.

2: NO2 Volume Mixing Ratio in Lowest Model Layer
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: O3 Volume Mixing Ratio in Lowest Model Layer
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: Daily Maximum O3 Volume Mixing Ratio in Lowest Model Layer
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: PM2.5 Mass Mixing Ratio in Lowest Model Layer
4: Mass fraction of atmospheric particulate compounds with an aerodynamic diameter of less than or equal to 2.5 micrometers. To specify the relative humidity and temperature at which the particle size applies, provide scalar coordinate variables with the standard names of 'relative_humidity' and 'air_temperature'.

2: Salt Flux into Sea Water from Rivers
4: This field is physical, and it arises when rivers carry a nonzero salt content.  Often this is zero, with rivers assumed to be fresh.

2: Floating Ice Shelf Area Percentage
4: Percentage of grid cell covered by floating ice shelf, the component of the ice sheet that is flowing over sea water

2: Land Ice Area Percentage
4: Percentage of grid cell covered by land ice (ice sheet, ice shelf, ice cap, glacier)

2: Grounded Ice Sheet Area Percentage
4: Percentage of grid cell covered by grounded ice sheet

2: Percentage of the grid  cell occupied by land (including lakes)
4: Percentage of horizontal area occupied by land.

2: Sea Area Percentage
4: Percentage of horizontal area occupied by ocean.

2: Percentage Cover by Shrub
4: Percentage of entire grid cell  that is covered by shrub.

2: Total Dissolved Inorganic Silicon Concentration
4: Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called 'molarity', and is used in the construction 'mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y', where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. 'Dissolved inorganic silicon' means the sum of all inorganic silicon in solution (including silicic acid and its first dissociated anion SiO(OH)3-).

2: Age of Sea Ice
4: Age of sea ice

2: Sea-Ice Area Flux Through Straits
4: net (sum of transport in all directions) sea ice area transport through the following four passages, positive into the Arctic Ocean 1. Fram Strait = (11.5W,81.3N to (10.5E,79.6N) 2. Canadian Archipelago = (128.2W,70.6N) to (59.3W,82.1N) 3. Barents opening = (16.8E,76.5N) to (19.2E,70.2N) 4. Bering Strait = (171W,66.2N) to (166W,65N)

2: Sea-Ice Area North
4: total area of sea ice in the Northern hemisphere

2: Sea-Ice Area South
4: total area of sea ice in the Southern hemisphere

2: Compressive Sea Ice Strength
4: Computed strength of the ice pack, defined as the energy (J m-2) dissipated per unit area removed from the ice pack under compression, and assumed proportional to the change in potential energy caused by ridging. For Hibler-type models, this is P (= P*h exp(-C(1-A)) where P* is compressive strength, h ice thickness, A compactness and C strength reduction constant).

2: Sea-Ice Area Percentage (Ocean Grid)
4: Percentage of grid cell covered by sea ice

2: Sea-Ice Area Percentage (Atmospheric Grid)
4: Percentage of grid cell covered by sea ice

2: Sea-Ice Area Percentage Tendency Due to Dynamics
4: Total change in sea-ice area fraction through dynamics-related processes (advection, divergence...)

2: Sea-Ice Area Percentage Tendency Due to Thermodynamics
4: Total change in sea-ice area fraction through thermodynamic processes

2: Divergence of the Sea-Ice Velocity Field
4: Divergence of sea-ice velocity field (first shear strain invariant)

2: Sea-Ice Mass Change from Dynamics
4: Total change in sea-ice mass through dynamics-related processes (advection,...) divided by grid-cell area

2: Sea-Ice Mass Change Through Evaporation and Sublimation
4: The rate of change of sea-ice mass change through evaporation and sublimation divided by grid-cell area

2: Sea-Ice Mass Change Through Basal Growth
4: The rate of change of sea ice mass due to vertical growth of existing sea ice at its base divided by grid-cell area.

2: Sea-Ice Mass Change Through Growth in Supercooled Open Water (Frazil)
4: The rate of change of sea ice mass due to sea ice formation in supercooled water (often through frazil formation) divided by grid-cell area. Together, sidmassgrowthwat and sidmassgrowthbot should give total ice growth

2: Lateral Sea Ice Melt Rate
4: The rate of change of sea ice mass through lateral melting divided by grid-cell area (report 0 if not explicitly calculated thermodynamically)

2: Sea-Ice Mass Change Through Bottom Melting
4: The rate of change of sea ice mass through melting at the ice bottom divided by grid-cell area

2: Sea-Ice Mass Change Through Surface Melting
4: The rate of change of sea ice mass through melting at the ice surface divided by grid-cell area

2: Sea-Ice Mass Change Through Snow-to-Ice Conversion
4: The rate of change of sea ice mass due to transformation of snow to sea ice divided by grid-cell area

2: Sea-Ice Mass Change from Thermodynamics
4: Total change in sea-ice mass from thermodynamic processes divided by grid-cell area

2: X-Component of Sea-Ice Mass Transport
4: Includes transport of both sea ice and snow by advection

2: Y-Component of Sea-Ice Mass Transport
4: Includes transport of both sea ice and snow by advection

2: Ocean Drag Coefficient
4: Oceanic drag coefficient that is used to calculate the oceanic momentum drag on sea ice

2: Atmospheric Drag Coefficient
4: Atmospheric drag coefficient that is used to calculate the atmospheric momentum drag on sea ice

2: Sea-Ice Extent North
4: Total area of all Northern-Hemisphere grid cells that are covered by at least 15 % areal fraction of sea ice

2: Sea-Ice Extent South
4: Total area of all Southern-Hemisphere grid cells that are covered by at least 15 % areal fraction of sea ice

2: Sea-Ice Freeboard
4: Mean height of sea-ice surface (=snow-ice interface when snow covered) above sea level

2: Net Conductive Heat Fluxes in Ice at the Bottom
4: the net heat conduction flux at the ice base

2: Net Conductive Heat Flux in Ice at the Surface
4: the net heat conduction flux at the ice surface

2: Freshwater Flux from Sea Ice
4: Total flux of fresh water from water into sea ice divided by grid-cell area; This flux is negative during ice growth (liquid water mass decreases, hence upward flux of freshwater), positive during ice melt (liquid water mass increases, hence downward flux of freshwater)

2: Freshwater Flux from Sea-Ice Surface
4: Total flux of fresh water from sea-ice surface into underlying ocean. This combines both surface melt water that drains directly into the ocean and the drainage of surface melt pond. By definition, this flux is always positive.

2: Net Latent Heat Flux over Sea Ice
4: the net latent heat flux over sea ice

2: Downwelling Longwave Flux over Sea Ice
4: the downwelling longwave flux over sea ice (always positive)

2: Upwelling Longwave Flux over Sea Ice
4: the upwelling longwave flux over sea ice (always negative)

2: Net Upward Sensible Heat Flux over Sea Ice
4: the net sensible heat flux over sea ice

2: Net Upward Sensible Heat Flux Under Sea Ice
4: the net sensible heat flux under sea ice from the ocean

2: Downwelling Shortwave Flux Under Sea Ice
4: The downwelling shortwave flux underneath sea ice (always positive)

2: Downwelling Shortwave Flux over Sea Ice
4: The downwelling shortwave flux over sea ice (always positive by sign convention)

2: Upwelling Shortwave Flux over Sea Ice
4: The upwelling shortwave flux over sea ice (always negative)

2: Coriolis Force Term in Force Balance (X-Component)
4: X-component of force on sea ice caused by coriolis force

2: Coriolis Force Term in Force Balance (Y-Component)
4: Y-component of force on sea ice caused by coriolis force

2: Internal Stress Term in Force Balance (X-Component)
4: X-component of force on sea ice caused by internal stress (divergence of sigma)

2: Internal Stress Term in Force Balance (Y-Component)
4: Y-component of force on sea ice caused by internal stress (divergence of sigma)

2: Sea-Surface Tilt Term in Force Balance (X-Component)
4: X-component of force on sea ice caused by sea-surface tilt

2: Sea-Surface Tilt Term in Force Balance (Y-Component)
4: Y-component of force on sea ice caused by sea-surface tilt

2: Sea-Ice Heat Content per Unit Area
4: Heat content of all ice in grid cell divided by total grid-cell area. Water at 0 Celsius is assumed to have a heat content of 0 J.  Does not include heat content of snow, but does include heat content of brine. Heat content is always negative, since both the sensible and the latent heat content of ice are less than that of water

2: Sea-Ice Area Percentages in Thickness Categories
4: Percentage of grid cell covered by each ice-thickness category (vector with one entry for each thickness category starting from the thinnest category, netcdf file should use thickness bounds of the categories as third coordinate axis)

2: Snow Area Percentages in Ice Thickness Categories
4: Percentage of grid cell covered by snow in each ice-thickness category (vector with one entry for each thickness category starting from the thinnest category, netcdf file should use thickness bounds of the categories as third coordinate axis)

2: Snow Thickness in Ice Thickness Categories
4: Actual thickness of snow in each  category (NOT volume divided by grid area),  (vector with one entry for each thickness category starting from the thinnest category, netcdf file should use thickness bounds of categories as third coordinate axis)

2: Sea-Ice Thickness in Thickness Categories
4: Actual (floe) thickness of sea ice in each  category (NOT volume divided by grid area),  (vector with one entry for each thickness category starting from the thinnest category, netcdf file should use thickness bounds of categories as third coordinate axis)

2: Silt Fraction
4: Volume fraction of silt in soil

2: Sea-Ice Mass per Area
4: Total mass of sea ice divided by grid-cell area

2: Sea Mass Area Flux Through Straits
4: net (sum of transport in all directions) sea ice area transport through the following four passages, positive into the Arctic Ocean 1. Fram Strait = (11.5W,81.3N to (10.5E,79.6N) 2. Canadian Archipelago = (128.2W,70.6N) to (59.3W,82.1N) 3. Barents opening = (16.8E,76.5N) to (19.2E,70.2N) 4. Bering Strait = (171W,66.2N) to (166W,65N)

2: Percentage Cover of Sea Ice by Meltpond
4: Percentage of sea ice, by area, which is covered by melt ponds, giving equal weight to every square metre of sea ice .

2: Meltpond Mass per Unit Area (as Depth)
4: Meltpond Depth

2: Thickness of Refrozen Ice on Melt Pond
4: Volume of refrozen ice on melt ponds divided by meltpond covered area

2: Surface Total Dissolved Inorganic Silicon Concentration
4: Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called 'molarity', and is used in the construction 'mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y', where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. 'Dissolved inorganic silicon' means the sum of all inorganic silicon in solution (including silicic acid and its first dissociated anion SiO(OH)3-).

2: Rainfall Rate over Sea Ice
4: mass of liquid precipitation falling onto sea ice divided by grid-cell area

2: Percentage Cover of Sea Ice by Ridging
4: Fraction of sea ice, by area, which is covered by sea ice ridges, giving equal weight to every square metre of sea ice .

2: Ridged Ice Thickness
4: Sea Ice Ridge Height (representing mean height over the ridged area)

2: Sea Ice Salinity
4: Mean sea-ice salinity of all sea ice in grid cell

2: Mass of Salt in Sea Ice per Area
4: Total mass of all salt in sea ice divided by grid-cell area

2: Maximum Shear of Sea-Ice Velocity Field
4: Maximum shear of sea-ice velocity field (second shear strain invariant)

2: Snow Area Percentage
4: Percentage of sea ice, by area, which is covered by snow, giving equal weight to every square metre of sea ice . Exclude snow that lies on land or land ice.

2: Snow Heat Content per Unit Area
4: Heat-content of all snow in grid cell divided by total grid-cell area. Snow-water equivalent at 0 Celsius is assumed to have a heat content of 0 J.  Does not include heat content of sea ice.

2: Snow Mass per Area
4: Total mass of snow on sea ice divided by sea-ice area.

2: Snow Thickness
4: Actual thickness of snow (snow volume divided by snow-covered area)

2: Sea-Ice Speed
4: Speed of ice (i.e. mean absolute velocity) to account for back-and-forth movement of the ice

2: Maximum Shear Stress in Sea Ice
4: Maximum shear stress in sea ice (second stress invariant)

2: Average Normal Stress in Sea Ice
4: Average normal stress in sea ice (first stress invariant)

2: X-Component of Atmospheric Stress on Sea Ice
4: X-component of atmospheric stress on sea ice

2: X-Component of Ocean Stress on Sea Ice
4: X-component of ocean stress on sea ice

2: Y-Component of Atmospheric Stress on Sea Ice
4: Y-component of atmospheric stress on sea ice

2: Y-Component of Ocean Stress on Sea Ice
4: Y-component of ocean stress on sea ice

2: Temperature at Ice-Ocean Interface
4: Report temperature at interface, NOT temperature within lowermost model layer

2: Temperature at Snow-Ice Interface
4: Report surface temperature of ice where snow thickness is zero

2: Surface Temperature of Sea Ice
4: Report surface temperature of snow where snow covers the sea ice.

2: Sea Ice Thickness
4: Actual (floe) thickness of sea ice (NOT volume divided by grid area as was done in CMIP5)

2: Fraction of Time Steps with Sea Ice
4: Fraction of time steps of the averaging period during which sea ice is present (siconc >0 ) in a grid cell

2: X-Component of Sea-Ice Velocity
4: The x-velocity of ice on native model grid

2: Y-Component of Sea-Ice Velocity
4: The y-velocity of ice on native model grid

2: Sea-Ice Volume per Area
4: Total volume of sea ice divided by grid-cell area (this used to be called ice thickness in CMIP5)

2: Sea-Ice Volume North
4: total volume of sea ice in the Northern hemisphere

2: Sea-Ice Volume South
4: total volume of sea ice in the Southern hemisphere

2: Northward Ocean Salt Transport
4: function of latitude, basin

2: Thickness of Soil Layers
4: 'Thickness' means the vertical extent of a layer. 'Cell' refers to a model grid cell.

2: Northward Ocean Salt Transport Due to Gyre
4: From all advective mass transport processes, resolved and parameterized.

2: Northward Ocean Salt Transport Due to Overturning
4: From all advective mass transport processes, resolved and parameterized.

2: Shallow Convective Mass Flux
4: The net mass flux represents the difference between the updraft and downdraft components.  For models with a distinct shallow convection scheme, this is calculated as convective mass flux divided by the area of the whole grid cell (not just the area of the cloud).

2: Snow Area Percentage
4: Percentage of each grid cell that is occupied by snow that rests on land portion of cell.

2: Ice Sheet Snow Cover Percentage
4: Percentage of each grid cell that is occupied by snow that rests on land portion of cell.

2: Snow Depth
4: where land over land, this is computed as the mean thickness of snow in the land portion of the grid cell (averaging over the entire land portion, including the snow-free fraction).  Reported as 0.0 where the land fraction is 0.

2: Snow Mass Rate of Change Through Advection by Sea-Ice Dynamics
4: The rate of change of snow mass through advection with sea ice divided by sea-ice area

2: Snow Mass Rate of Change Through Melt
4: the rate of change of snow mass through melt divided by sea-ice area

2: Snow Mass Rate of Change Through Snow-to-Ice Conversion
4: the rate of change of snow mass due to transformation of snow to sea ice divided by sea-ice area

2: Snow Mass Change Through Snow Fall
4: mass of solid precipitation falling onto sea ice divided by sea-ice area

2: Snow Mass Rate of Change Through Evaporation or Sublimation
4: the rate of change of snow mass through sublimation and evaporation divided by sea-ice area

2: Snow Mass Rate of Change Through Wind Drift of Snow
4: the rate of change of snow mass through wind drift of snow (from sea-ice into the sea) divided by sea-ice area

2: Surface Snow and Ice Refreeze Flux
4: Mass flux of surface meltwater which refreezes within the snowpack. Computed as the total refreezing on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell.

2: Ice Sheet Surface Snow and Ice Refreeze Flux
4: Mass flux of surface meltwater which refreezes within the snowpack. Computed as the total refreezing on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell.

2: Surface Snow and Ice Melt Flux
4: Loss of snow and ice mass resulting from surface melting. Computed as the total surface melt on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell.

2: Ice Sheet Surface Snow and Ice Melt Flux
4: Loss of snow and ice mass resulting from surface melting. Computed as the total surface melt on the land ice portion of the grid cell divided by land ice area in the grid cell.

2: Surface Snow Melt
4: The total surface snow melt rate on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; report as zero for snow-free land regions and missing where there is no land.

2: Snow Mass Flux Through Straits
4: net (sum of transport in all directions) sea ice area transport through the following four passages, positive into the Arctic Ocean 1. Fram Strait = (11.5W,81.3N to (10.5E,79.6N) 2. Canadian Archipelago = (128.2W,70.6N) to (59.3W,82.1N) 3. Barents opening = (16.8E,76.5N) to (19.2E,70.2N) 4. Bering Strait = (171W,66.2N) to (166W,65N)

2: Ice Sheet Surface Snow Melt
4: The total surface snow melt rate on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; report as zero for snow-free land regions and missing where there is no land.

2: Water Flowing out of Snowpack
4: Mass flow rate of water draining out of the snow pack.

2: Mass Fraction of Snow in Air
4: Snow mixing ratio

2: Refreezing of Water in the Snow
4: In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Surface snow and ice refreezing flux' means the mass flux of surface  meltwater which refreezes within the snow or firn.

2: Surface Snow Amount
4: The mass of surface snow on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; reported as missing where the land fraction is 0; excludes snow on vegetation canopy or on sea ice.

2: snow water equivalent intercepted by the vegetation
4: Total water mass of the snowpack (liquid or frozen), averaged over a grid cell and intercepted by the canopy.

2: Sea Water Salinity
4: Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.

2: SO2 Volume Mixing Ratio
4: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

2: Sea Water Salinity at Sea Floor
4: Model prognostic salinity at bottom-most model grid cell

2: Global Mean Sea Water Salinity
4: Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.

2: TOA Solar Irradiance for Each Band
4: Solar irradiance at a horizontal surface at top of atmosphere.

2: Depth Integral of Product of Sea Water Density and Prognostic Salinity
4: Full column sum of density*cell thickness*prognostic salinity. If the model is Boussinesq, then use Boussinesq reference density for the density factor.

2: Snow Soot Content
4: the entire land portion of the grid cell is considered, with snow soot content set to 0.0 in regions free of snow.

2: Sea Surface Salinity
4: Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.

2: Global Average Sea Surface Salinity
4: Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.

2: Square of Sea Surface Salinity
4: Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.

2: Surface Aqueous Partial Pressure of CO2
4: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. The partial pressure of a dissolved gas in sea water is the partial pressure in air with which it would be in equilibrium. The partial pressure of a gaseous constituent of air is the pressure which it alone would exert with unchanged temperature and number of moles per unit volume. The chemical formula for carbon dioxide is CO2.

2: Abiotic Surface Aqueous Partial Pressure of CO2
4: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. The chemical formula for carbon dioxide is CO2. In ocean biogeochemistry models, an 'abiotic analogue' is used to simulate the effect on a modelled variable when biological effects on ocean carbon concentration and alkalinity are ignored. The partial pressure of a gaseous constituent of air is the pressure which it alone would exert with unchanged temperature and number of moles per unit volume. The partial pressure of a dissolved gas in sea water is the partial pressure in air with which it would be in equilibrium. The partial pressure difference between sea water and air is positive when the partial pressure of the dissolved gas in sea water is greater than the partial pressure in air.

2: Natural Surface Aqueous Partial Pressure of CO2
4: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. The chemical formula for carbon dioxide is CO2. In ocean biogeochemistry models, a 'natural analogue' is used to simulate the effect on a modelled variable of imposing preindustrial atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations, even when the model as a whole may be subjected to varying forcings. The partial pressure of a gaseous constituent of air is the pressure which it alone would exert with unchanged temperature and number of moles per unit volume. The partial pressure of a dissolved gas in sea water is the partial pressure in air with which it would be in equilibrium. The partial pressure difference between sea water and air is positive when the partial pressure of the dissolved gas in sea water is greater than the partial pressure in air.

2: Land Ice Basal Drag
4: Magnitude of basal drag at land ice base

2: Surface Water Storage
4: Total liquid water storage, other than soil, snow or interception storage (i.e. lakes, river channel or depression storage).

2: Isotopic Ratio of Oxygen-17 in Sea Water
4: Ratio of abundance of oxygen-17 (17O) atoms to oxygen-16 (16O) atoms in sea water

2: Isotopic Ratio of Oxygen-18 in Sea Water
4: Ratio of abundance of oxygen-18 (18O) atoms to oxygen-16 (16O) atoms in sea water

2: Isotopic Ratio of Deuterium in Sea Water
4: Ratio of abundance of hydrogen-2 (2H) atoms to hydrogen-1 (1H) atoms in sea water

2: Snow Water Equivalent on Land-Use Tile
4: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'lwe' means liquid water equivalent. 'Amount' means mass per unit area. The construction lwe_thickness_of_X_amount or _content means the vertical extent of a layer of liquid water having the same mass per unit area. Surface amount refers to the amount on the ground, excluding that on the plant or vegetation canopy.

2: Shortwave Heating Rate Due to Volcanic Aerosols
4: Shortwave heating rate due to volcanic aerosols to be diagnosed through double radiation call

2: All-Sky Surface Shortwave Radiative Flux Due to Dust
4: The direct radiative effect refers to the instantaneous radiative impact on the Earth's energy balance, excluding secondary effects such as changes in cloud cover.

2: Clear-Sky Surface Shortwave Radiative Flux Due to Dust
4: The direct radiative effect refers to the instantaneous radiative impact on the Earth's energy balance, excluding secondary effects such as changes in cloud cover. Calculated in clear-sky conditions.

2: All-Sky Shortwave Flux Due to Dust at Toa
4: Instantaneous forcing is the radiative flux change caused instantaneously by an imposed change in radiative forcing agent (greenhouse gases, aerosol, solar radiation, etc.).

2: clear sky  Shortwave flux due to dust at toa
4: Instantaneous forcing is the radiative flux change caused instantaneously by an imposed change in radiative forcing agent (greenhouse gases, aerosol, solar radiation, etc.).

2: TOA Outgoing Clear-Sky Shortwave Flux Due to Volcanic Aerosols
4: Downwelling shortwave flux due to volcanic aerosols at TOA under clear sky to be diagnosed through double radiation call

2: Solar Zenith Angle
4: The angle between the line of sight to the sun and the local vertical

2: Mean-Squared Air Temperature
4: Air temperature squared

2: Depth of 20 degree Celsius Isotherm
4: This quantity, sometimes called the 'isotherm depth', is the depth (if it exists) at which the sea water potential temperature equals some specified value. This value should be specified in a scalar coordinate variable. Depth is the vertical distance below the surface. Potential temperature is the temperature a parcel of air or sea water would have if moved adiabatically to sea level pressure.

2: Air Temperature
4: Air Temperature

2: Air Temperature
4: Temperature on the 500 hPa surface

2: Air Temperature
4: Air temperature at 700hPa

2: Air Temperature
4: Air temperature at 850hPa

2: Total Alkalinity
4: total alkalinity equivalent concentration (including carbonate, nitrogen, silicate, and borate components)

2: Natural Total Alkalinity
4: total alkalinity equivalent concentration (including carbonate, borate, phosphorus, silicon, and nitrogen components) at preindustrial atmospheric xCO2

2: Surface Natural Total Alkalinity
4: total alkalinity equivalent concentration (including carbonate, borate, phosphorus, silicon, and nitrogen components) at preindustrial atmospheric xCO2

2: Surface Total Alkalinity
4: total alkalinity equivalent concentration (including carbonate, borate, phosphorus, silicon, and nitrogen components)

2: Near-Surface Air Temperature
4: near-surface (usually, 2 meter) air temperature

2: Ice Sheet Near-Surface Air Temperature
4: near-surface (usually, 2 meter) air temperature

2: Near-Surface Air Temperature on Land Use Tile
4: Air temperature is the bulk temperature of the air, not the surface (skin) temperature.

2: Daily Maximum Near-Surface Air Temperature
4: maximum near-surface (usually, 2 meter) air temperature (add cell_method attribute 'time: max')

2: Daily Maximum Near-Surface Air Temperature over Crop Tile
4: maximum near-surface (usually, 2 meter) air temperature (add cell_method attribute 'time: max')

2: Daily Minimum Near-Surface Air Temperature
4: minimum near-surface (usually, 2 meter) air temperature (add cell_method attribute 'time: min')

2: Daily Minimum Near-Surface Air Temperature over Crop Tile
4: minimum near-surface (usually, 2 meter) air temperature (add cell_method attribute 'time: min')

2: Tropopause Air Temperature
4: 2D monthly mean thermal tropopause calculated using WMO tropopause definition on 3d temperature

2: Momentum Flux
4: module of the momentum lost by the atmosphere to the surface.

2: Surface Downward Eastward Wind Stress
4: Downward eastward wind stress at the surface

2: Sea Water Surface Downward X Stress Correction
4: This is the stress on the liquid ocean from overlying atmosphere, sea ice, ice shelf, etc.

2: Sea Water Surface Downward X Stress
4: This is the stress on the liquid ocean from overlying atmosphere, sea ice, ice shelf, etc.

2: Eastward Surface Stress from Planetary Boundary Layer Scheme
4: The  downward eastward stress associated with the models parameterization of the planetary boundary layer. (This request is related to a WGNE effort to understand how models parameterize the surface stresses.)

2: Surface Downward Northward Wind Stress
4: Downward northward wind stress at the surface

2: Sea Water Surface Downward Y Stress Correction
4: This is the stress on the liquid ocean from overlying atmosphere, sea ice, ice shelf, etc.

2: Sea Water Surface Downward Y Stress
4: This is the stress on the liquid ocean from overlying atmosphere, sea ice, ice shelf, etc.

2: Northward Surface Stress from Planetary Boundary Layer Scheme
4: The  downward northward stress associated with the models parameterization of the planetary boundary layer. (This request is related to a WGNE effort to understand how models parameterize the surface stresses.)

2: Vegetation Canopy Temperature
4: Vegetation temperature, averaged over all vegetation types

2: 2m Dewpoint Temperature
4: Dew point temperature is the temperature at which a parcel of air reaches saturation upon being cooled at constant pressure and specific humidity.

2: Total Surface Mass Balance Flux
4: The total surface mass balance flux over land ice is a spatial integration of the surface mass balance flux

2: Total Basal Mass Balance Flux
4: The total basal mass balance flux over land ice is a spatial integration of the basal mass balance flux

2: Total Calving Flux
4: The total calving flux over land ice is a spatial integration of the calving flux

2: Temperature of Bare Soil
4: Surface bare soil temperature

2: Sea Water Potential Temperature
4: Diagnostic should be contributed even for models using conservative temperature as prognostic field.

2: Global Average Sea Water Potential Temperature
4: Diagnostic should be contributed even for models using conservative temperature as prognostic field

2: Vertically Averaged Sea Water Potential Temperature
4: Vertical average of the sea water potential temperature through the whole ocean depth

2: Depth Average Potential Temperature of Upper 2000m
4: Upper 2000m, 2D field

2: Depth Average Potential Temperature of Upper 300m
4: Upper 300m, 2D field

2: Depth Average Potential Temperature of Upper 700m
4: Upper 700m, 2D field

2: Ocean Model Cell Thickness
4: 'Thickness' means the vertical extent of a layer. 'Cell' refers to a model grid-cell.

2: Tendency of Specific Humidity
4: Tendency of Specific Humidity

2: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Advection
4: Tendency of Specific Humidity due to Advection

2: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Convection
4: Tendencies from cumulus convection scheme.

2: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Numerical Diffusion
4: Tendency of specific humidity due to numerical diffusion.This includes any horizontal or vertical numerical moisture diffusion not associated with the parametrized moist physics or the resolved dynamics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be excluded, as should any diffusion which is included in the terms from the resolved dynamics.   This term is required to check the closure of the moisture budget.

2: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Model Physics
4: Tendency of specific humidity due to model physics. This includes sources and sinks from parametrized moist physics (e.g. convection, boundary layer, stratiform condensation/evaporation, etc.) and excludes sources and sinks from resolved dynamics or from horizontal or vertical numerical diffusion not associated with model physics.  For example any diffusive mixing by the boundary layer scheme would be included.

2: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Boundary Layer Mixing
4: Includes all boundary layer terms including diffusive terms.

2: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Stratiform Clouds and Precipitation
4: The phrase 'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time. 'Specific' means per unit mass. Specific humidity is the mass fraction of water vapor in (moist) air. The specification of a physical process by the phrase 'due_to_' process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. A variable with the standard name of tendency_of_specific_humidity_due_to_stratiform_cloud_and_precipitation should contain the effects of all processes which convert stratiform clouds and precipitation to or from water vapor. In an atmosphere model, stratiform cloud is that produced by large-scale convergence (not the convection schemes).

2: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Stratiform Cloud and Precipitation and Boundary Layer Mixing
4: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Stratiform Cloud and Precipitation and Boundary Layer Mixing  (to be specified only in  models which do not separate budget terms for stratiform cloud, precipitation and boundary layer schemes.  Includes all boundary layer terms including and diffusive terms.)

2: Tendency of Ocean Eddy Kinetic Energy Content Due to Parameterized Eddy Advection
4: Depth integrated impacts on kinetic energy arising from parameterized eddy-induced advection. For CMIP5, this diagnostic was 3d, whereas the CMIP6 depth integrated diagnostic is sufficient for many purposes and reduces archive requirements.

2: Tendency of Ocean Potential Energy Content
4: Rate that work is done against vertical stratification, as measured by the vertical heat and salt diffusivity. Report here as depth integrated two-dimensional field.

2: Tendency of Ocean Potential Energy Content Due to Tides
4: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area.  Potential energy is the sum of the gravitational potential energy relative to the geoid and the centripetal potential energy. (The geopotential is the specific potential energy.)  'Due to tides' means due to all astronomical gravity changes which manifest as tides.  No distinction is made between different tidal components. The specification of a physical process by the phrase due_to_process means that the quantity named is a  single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity  named by omitting the phrase.  'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time.

2: Tendency of Ocean Potential Energy Content Due to Background
4: 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area.  Potential energy is the sum of the gravitational potential energy relative to the geoid and the centripetal potential energy. (The geopotential is the specific potential energy.)  'Due to background' means caused by a time invariant imposed field which may be either constant over the globe or spatially varying, depending on the ocean model used. The specification of a physical process by the phrase due_to_process means that the quantity named is a  single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity  named by omitting the phrase.  'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time.

2: Tendency of Air Temperature
4: Tendency of Air Temperature

2: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Advection
4: Tendency of Air Temperature due to Advection

2: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Convection
4: Tendencies from cumulus convection scheme.

2: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Numerical Diffusion
4: This includes any horizontal or vertical numerical temperature diffusion not associated with the parametrized moist physics or the resolved dynamics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be excluded, as should any diffusion which is included in the terms from the resolved dynamics.   This term is required to check the closure of the temperature budget.

2: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Model Physics
4: Tendency of air temperature due to model physics. This includes sources and sinks from parametrized physics (e.g. radiation, convection, boundary layer, stratiform condensation/evaporation, etc.). It excludes sources and sinks from resolved dynamics and numerical diffusion not associated with parametrized physics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be included, while numerical diffusion applied in addition to physics or resolved dynamics should be excluded.  This term is required to check the closure of the heat budget.

2: Temperature Tendency Due to Non-Orographic Gravity Wave Dissipation
4: Temperature tendency due to dissipation of parameterized nonorographic gravity waves.

2: Temperature Tendency Due to Orographic Gravity Wave Dissipation
4: Temperature tendency due to dissipation of parameterized orographic gravity waves.

2: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Boundary Layer Mixing
4: Includes all boundary layer terms including diffusive terms.

2: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Radiative Heating
4: Tendency of Air Temperature due to Radiative Heating

2: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Longwave Radiative Heating
4: Tendency of air temperature due to longwave radiative heating

2: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Clear Sky Longwave Radiative Heating
4: Tendency of Air Temperature due to Clear Sky Longwave Radiative Heating

2: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Shortwave Radiative Heating
4: Tendency of air temperature due to shortwave radiative heating

2: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Clear Sky Shortwave Radiative Heating
4: Tendency of Air Temperature due to Clear Sky Shortwave Radiative Heating

2: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Stratiform Clouds and Precipitation
4: The phrase 'tendency_of_X' means derivative of X with respect to time. Air temperature is the bulk temperature of the air, not the surface (skin) temperature. The specification of a physical process by the phrase 'due_to_' process means that the quantity named is a single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase. A variable with the standard name tendency_of_air_temperature_due_to_stratiform_cloud_and_precipitation should contain net latent heating effects of all processes which convert stratiform clouds and precipitation between water vapour, liquid or ice phases. In an atmosphere model, stratiform cloud is that produced by large-scale convergence (not the convection schemes).

2: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Stratiform Cloud and Precipitation and Boundary Layer Mixing
4: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Stratiform Cloud and Precipitation and Boundary Layer Mixing (to be specified only in  models which do not separate cloud, precipitation and boundary layer terms.  Includes all boundary layer terms including diffusive ones.)

2: Sea Water Potential Temperature at Sea Floor
4: Potential temperature at the ocean bottom-most grid cell.

2: Bedrock Altitude
4: The bedrock topography beneath the land ice

2: Sea Surface Temperature
4: Temperature of upper boundary of the liquid ocean, including temperatures below sea-ice and floating ice shelves.

2: Global Average Sea Surface Temperature
4: Temperature of upper boundary of the liquid ocean, including temperatures below sea-ice and floating ice shelves.

2: Square of Sea Surface Temperature
4: Square of temperature of liquid ocean.

2: Total Column Ozone
4: Total ozone column calculated at 0 degrees C and 1 bar, such that 1m = 1e5 DU.

2: Permafrost Layer Thickness
4: The mean thickness of the permafrost layer in the land portion of the grid cell.  Reported as zero in permafrost-free regions.

2: Surface Radiative Temperature
4: Effective radiative surface temperature, averaged over the grid cell

2: Transpiration
4: Transpiration (may include dew formation as a negative flux).

2: Tree Cover Percentage
4: Percentage of entire grid cell  that is covered by trees.

2: Broadleaf Deciduous Tree Area Percentage
4: This is the percentage of the entire grid cell that is covered by broadleaf deciduous trees.

2: Broadleaf Evergreen Tree Area Percentage
4: This is the percentage of the entire grid cell that is covered by broadleaf evergreen trees.

2: Needleleaf Deciduous Tree Area Percentage
4: This is the percentage of the entire grid cell that is covered by needleleaf deciduous trees.

2: Needleleaf Evergreen Tree Area Percentage
4: This is the percentage of the entire grid cell that is covered by needleleaf evergreen trees.

2: Percentage Cover by Primary Deciduous Tree
4: Percentage of the entire grid cell  that is covered by total primary deciduous trees.

2: Percentage Cover by Primary Evergreen Trees
4: Percentage of entire grid cell  that is covered by primary evergreen trees.

2: Percentage Cover by Secondary Deciduous Trees
4: Percentage of entire grid cell  that is covered by secondary deciduous trees.

2: Percentage Cover by Secondary Evergreen Trees
4: Percentage of entire grid cell  that is covered by secondary evergreen trees.

2: Tropospheric Ozone Column
4: Tropospheric ozone column, should be consistent with definition of tropopause used to calculate the pressure of the tropopause (ptp). Calculated at 0 degrees C and 1 bar, such that 1m = 1e5 DU.

2: Surface Temperature
4: Temperature of the lower boundary of the atmosphere

2: Ice Sheet Surface Temperature
4: Temperature of the lower boundary of the atmosphere

2: Temperature of Soil
4: Temperature of soil. Reported as missing for grid cells with no land.

2: Land Surface Temperature
4: Temperature of the lower boundary of the atmosphere

2: Surface Temperature Where Land or Sea Ice
4: Surface temperature of all surfaces except open ocean.

2: Surface Temperature on Landuse Tile
4: Surface temperature (i.e. temperature at which long-wave radiation emitted)

2: Snow Internal Temperature
4: This temperature is averaged over all the snow in the grid cell that rests on land or land ice.  When computing the time-mean here, the time samples, weighted by the mass of snow on the land portion of the grid cell, are accumulated and then divided by the sum of the weights.   Reported as missing in regions free of snow on land.

2: Ice Sheet Snow Internal Temperature
4: This temperature is averaged over all the snow in the grid cell that rests on land or land ice.  When computing the time-mean here, the time samples, weighted by the mass of snow on the land portion of the grid cell, are accumulated and then divided by the sum of the weights.   Reported as missing in regions free of snow on land.

2: Snow Surface Temperature
4: Temperature of the snow surface as it interacts with the atmosphere, averaged over a grid cell.

2: Turnover Rate of Each Model Soil Carbon Pool
4: defined as 1/(turnover time) for each soil pool. Use the same pools reported under cSoilPools

2: Air Temperature at Cloud Top
4: cloud_top refers to the top of the highest cloud. Air temperature is the bulk temperature of the air, not the surface (skin) temperature.

2: Product of Air Temperature and Omega
4: Product of air temperature and pressure tendency

2: Mean-Squared Eastward Wind Speed
4: u*u

2: Eastward Wind
4: Zonal wind (positive in a eastward direction).

2: Eastward Wind at 10hPa
4: Zonal wind on the 10 hPa surface

2: Eastward Wind at 100m
4: Zonal wind at 100m height

2: Eastward Near-Surface Wind
4: Eastward component of the near-surface (usually, 10 meters)  wind

2: UGRID Grid Specification
4: Ony required for models with unstructured grids: this label should be used for a file containing information about the grid structure, following the UGRID convention.

2: Ocean Mass X Transport
4: X-ward mass transport from resolved and parameterized advective transport.

2: Sea Water X Velocity
4: Prognostic x-ward velocity component resolved by the model.

2: Eastward Humidity Transport

2: Product of Air Temperature and Eastward Wind
4: Product of air temperature and eastward wind

4: Tendency of the zonal mean zonal wind due to the divergence of the Eliassen-Palm flux.

2: Eastward Acceleration Due to Non-Orographic Gravity Wave Drag

2: Eastward Acceleration Due to Orographic Gravity Wave Drag
4: Tendency of the eastward wind by parameterized orographic gravity waves.

4: Tendency of zonally averaged eastward wind, by the residual northward wind advection (on the native model grid). Reference: Andrews et al (1987): Middle Atmospheric Dynamics. Academic Press.

4: Tendency of zonally averaged eastward wind, by the residual upward wind advection (on the native model grid). Reference: Andrews et al (1987): Middle Atmospheric Dynamics. Academic Press.

4: u*v

4: Percentage of grid cell that is covered by vegetation.This SHOULD be the sum of tree, grass (natural and pasture), crop and shrub fractions.

2: Height of Pastures
4: Vegetation height averaged over the pasture fraction of a grid cell.

2: Height of Shrubs
4: Vegetation height averaged over the shrub fraction of a grid cell.

2: Height of Trees

4: Y-ward mass transport from resolved and parameterized advective transport.

4: Total volume of liquid sea water.

2: Virtual Salt Flux Correction
4: It is set to zero in models which receive a real water flux.

2: Virtual Salt Flux into Sea Water Due to Evaporation

2: Virtual Salt Flux into Sea Water Due to Rainfall
4: zero for models using real water fluxes.

2: Virtual Salt Flux into Sea Water from Rivers
4: zero for models using real water fluxes.

2: Virtual Salt Flux into Sea Water Due to Sea Ice Thermodynamics
4: This variable measures the virtual salt flux into sea water due to the melting of sea ice. It is set to zero in models which receive a real water flux.

2: Product of Air Temperature and Northward Wind
4: Product of air temperature and northward wind

4: Transformed Eulerian Mean Diagnostics v*, meridional component of the residual meridional circulation (v*, w*) derived from 6 hr or higher frequency data fields (use instantaneous daily fields or 12 hr fields if the 6 hr data are not available).

2: Northward Acceleration Due to Non-Orographic Gravity Wave Drag
4: Tendency of the northward wind by parameterized nonorographic gravity waves.  (Note that CF name tables only have a general northward tendency for all gravity waves, and we need it separated by type.)

4: Tendency of the northward wind by parameterized orographic gravity waves.  (Note that CF name tables only have a general northward tendency for all gravity waves, and we need it separated by type.)

2: Product of Northward Wind and Omega
4: v*omega

4: A velocity is a vector quantity. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). Upward air velocity is the vertical component of the 3D air velocity vector. The standard name downward_air_velocity may be used for a vector component with the opposite sign convention.

2: Omega (=dp/dt)
4: Omega (vertical velocity in pressure coordinates, positive downwards)

2: Mean-Squared Vertical Velocity (Omega)
4: omega*omega

2: Pressure Tendency
4: Omega (vertical velocity in pressure coordinates, positive downwards) at 500hPa level;

2: Wet Bulb Potential Temperature
4: Wet bulb potential temperature

4: Surface deposition rate of black carbon (dry mass) due to wet processes

2: Wet Deposition Rate of Dust
4: Surface deposition rate of dust (dry mass) due to wet processes

4: Net upward flux of methane (NH4) from wetlands (areas where water covers the soil, or is present either at or near the surface of the soil all year or for varying periods of time during the year, including during the growing season).

2: Grid Averaged Methane Consumption (Methanotrophy) from Wetlands

4: Biological emissions (methanogenesis) of methane (NH4) from wetlands (areas where water covers the soil, or is present either at or near the surface of the soil all year or for varying periods of time during the year, including during the growing season).

2: Wetland Percentage Cover
4: Percentage of grid cell covered by wetland. Report only one year if  fixed percentage is used, or time series if values are determined dynamically.

2: Wet Deposition Rate of NH3
4: Surface deposition rate of ammonia (NH3) due to wet processes

2: Wet Deposition Rate of NH4
4: Surface deposition rate of ammonium (NH4) due to wet processes

2: Wet Deposition Rate of NOy Including Aerosol Nitrate
4: NOy is the sum of all simulated oxidized nitrogen species, out of NO, NO2, HNO3, HNO4, NO3 aerosol, NO3 (radical), N2O5, PAN, other organic nitrates.

2: Wet Deposition Rate of Dry Aerosol Total Organic Matter
4: Deposition rate of organic matter in aerosols (measured by the dry mass) due to wet processes

2: Wet Deposition Rate of SO2
4: Deposition rate of sulfur dioxide due to wet processes

2: Wet Deposition Rate of SO4
4: Deposition rate of sulfate aerosols (measured by the dry mass) due to wet processes

2: Wet Deposition Rate of Sea-Salt Aerosol
4: Deposition rate of sea salt aerosols (measured by the dry mass) due to wet processes

2: Water Flux Correction
4: Computed as the water flux into the ocean due to flux correction divided by the area of the ocean portion of the grid cell.

2: Water Flux into Sea Water
4: Computed as the water flux into the ocean divided by the area of the ocean portion of the grid cell. This is the sum *wfonocorr* and *wfcorr*.

2: Water Flux into Sea Water Without Flux Correction
4: Computed as the water flux (without flux correction) into the ocean divided by the area of the ocean portion of the grid cell.

2: Wilting Point
4: Percentage water content of soil by volume at the wilting point. The wilting point of soil is the water content below which plants cannot extract sufficient water to balance their loss through transpiration.

2: Upward Ocean Mass Transport
4: Upward mass transport from resolved and parameterized advective transport.

2: Sea Water Vertical Velocity
4: A velocity is a vector quantity. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward).

2: Maximum Wind Speed of Gust at 100m
4: Wind speed gust maximum at 100m above surface

2: Maximum Wind Speed of Gust at 10m
4: Wind speed gust maximum at 10m above surface

2: Water Table Depth
4: Depth is the vertical distance below the surface. The water table is the surface below which the soil is saturated with water such that all pore spaces are filled.

2: Transformed Eulerian Mean Upward Wind
4: Transformed Eulerian Mean Diagnostics w*, upward component of the residual meridional circulation (v*, w*) derived from 6 hr or higher frequency data fields (use instantaneous daily fields or 12 hr fields if the 6 hr data are not available). Scale height: 6950 m

2: Eastward Gravity Wave Drag
4: Parameterised x-component of gravity wave drag

2: X-Component of Land Ice Basal Velocity
4: A velocity is a vector quantity. 'x' indicates a vector component along the grid x-axis, positive with increasing x. 'Land ice' means glaciers, ice-caps and ice-sheets resting on bedrock and also includes ice-shelves. 'basal' means the lower boundary of the land ice.

2: X-Component of Land Ice Vertical Mean Velocity
4: The vertical mean land ice velocity is the average from the bedrock to the surface of the ice

2: X-Component of Land Ice Surface Velocity
4: A velocity is a vector quantity. 'x' indicates a vector component along the grid x-axis, positive with increasing x. 'Land ice' means glaciers, ice-caps and ice-sheets resting on bedrock and also includes ice-shelves. The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere.

2: Northward Gravity Wave Drag
4: Parameterised y- component of gravity wave drag

2: Y-Component of Land Ice Basal Velocity
4: A velocity is a vector quantity. 'y' indicates a vector component along the grid y-axis, positive with increasing y. 'Land ice' means glaciers, ice-caps and ice-sheets resting on bedrock and also includes ice-shelves. 'basal' means the lower boundary of the land ice.

2: Y-Component of Land Ice Vertical Mean Velocity
4: The vertical mean land ice velocity is the average from the bedrock to the surface of the ice

2: Y-Component of Land Ice Surface Velocity
4: A velocity is a vector quantity. 'y' indicates a vector component along the grid y-axis, positive with increasing y. 'Land ice' means glaciers, ice-caps and ice-sheets resting on bedrock and also includes ice-shelves. The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere.'

2: Altitude of Model Full-Levels
4: Height of full model levels above a reference ellipsoid. A reference ellipsoid is a mathematical figure that approximates the geoid. The geoid is a surface of constant geopotential with which mean sea level would coincide if the ocean were at rest. The ellipsoid is an approximation because the geoid is an irregular shape. A number of reference ellipsoids are defined for use in the field of geodesy. To specify which reference ellipsoid is being used, a grid_mapping variable should be attached to the data variable as described in Chapter 5.6 of the CF Convention.

2: Depth Below Geoid of Ocean Layer
4: Depth below geoid

2: Geopotential Height
4: Geopotential is the sum of the specific gravitational potential energy relative to the geoid and the specific centripetal potential energy. Geopotential height is the geopotential divided by the standard acceleration due to gravity. It is numerically similar to the altitude (or geometric height) and not to the quantity with standard name height, which is relative to the surface.

2: Geopotential Height at 10hPa
4: Geopotential height on the 10hPa surface

2: Geopotential Height at 100hPa
4: Geopotential height on the 100 hPa surface

2: Geopotential Height at 1000hPa
4: Geopotential height on the 1000 hPa surface

2: Geopotential Height at 500hPa
4: geopotential height on the 500 hPa surface

2: Altitude of Model Half-Levels
4: Height of model half-levels above a reference ellipsoid. A reference ellipsoid is a mathematical figure that approximates the geoid. The geoid is a surface of constant geopotential with which mean sea level would coincide if the ocean were at rest. The ellipsoid is an approximation because the geoid is an irregular shape. A number of reference ellipsoids are defined for use in the field of geodesy. To specify which reference ellipsoid is being used, a grid_mapping variable should be attached to the data variable as described in Chapter 5.6 of the CF Convention.

2: Depth Below Geoid of Interfaces Between Ocean Layers
4: Depth below geoid

2: Mole Concentration of Mesozooplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water
4: carbon  concentration from mesozooplankton (20-200 um) component alone

2: Surface Mole Concentration of Mesozooplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water
4: carbon  concentration from mesozooplankton (20-200 um) component alone

2: Mole Concentration of Microzooplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water
4: carbon  concentration from the microzooplankton (<20 um) component alone

2: Surface Mole Concentration of Microzooplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water
4: carbon  concentration from the microzooplankton (<20 um) component alone

2: Mole Concentration of Other Zooplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water
4: carbon from additional zooplankton component concentrations alone (e.g. Micro, meso).  Since the models all have different numbers of components, this variable has been included to provide a check for intercomparison between models since some phytoplankton groups are supersets.

2: Surface Mole Concentration of Other Zooplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water
4: carbon from additional zooplankton component concentrations alone (e.g. Micro, meso).  Since the models all have different numbers of components, this variable has been included to provide a check for intercomparison between models since some phytoplankton groups are supersets.

2: Height of Boundary Layer
4: The atmosphere boundary layer thickness is the 'depth' or 'height' of the (atmosphere) planetary boundary layer.

2: Zonal Mean Longwave Heating Rate Due to Volcanic Aerosols
4: longwave heating rate due to volcanic aerosols to be diagnosed through double radiation call, zonal average values required

2: Zonal Mean Shortwave Heating Rate Due to Volcanic Aerosols
4: shortwave heating rate due to volcanic aerosols to be diagnosed through double radiation call, zonal average values required

2: Zonal Mean Diabatic Heating Rates
4: The diabatic heating rates due to all the processes that may change potential temperature

2: Depth of Oxygen Minimum Concentration
4: Depth of vertical minimum concentration of dissolved oxygen gas (if two, then the shallower)

2: Zooplankton Carbon Concentration
4: sum of zooplankton carbon component concentrations

2: Surface Zooplankton Carbon Concentration
4: sum of zooplankton carbon component concentrations

2: Sea Surface Height Above Geoid
4: This is the dynamic sea level, so should have zero global area mean. It should not include inverse barometer depressions from sea ice.

2: Square of Sea Surface Height Above Geoid
4: Surface ocean geoid defines z=0.

2: Global Average Thermosteric Sea Level Change
4: There is no CMIP6 request for zosga nor zossga.

2: Aragonite Saturation Depth
4: Depth of aragonite saturation horizon (0 if undersaturated at all depths, 'missing' if supersaturated at all depths; if multiple horizons exist, the shallowest should be taken).

2: Calcite Saturation Depth
4: Depth of calcite saturation horizon (0 if undersaturated at all depths, and missing saturated through whole depth; if two or more horizons exist, then the shallowest is reported)

2: Tropopause Altitude Above Geoid
4: 2D monthly mean thermal tropopause calculated using WMO tropopause definition on 3d temperature

2: Upward Component of Land-Ice Basal Velocity
4: A velocity is a vector quantity. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). 'basal' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere

2: Upward Component of Land-Ice Surface Velocity
4: A velocity is a vector quantity. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere
